  2773. The brush head is a much simpler design than the Elite version and MUCH less likely to harbor residue that goes stinky over time like the Elite head.
  2774. Very inexpensive tooth electronic brushing and performs it in half the time of a regular toothbrush.
  2775. (gunk doesn't build up), has different mode cleanings (one for a quick brush when i'm running late for work and another mode
  2776. and I got it for a good price - when this bites the dust, I will chance a less expensive model as a replacement.
  2777. Only a mild complaint.
  2778. fast forward a year and a half later the replacement brush just died, simply stopped...again.
  2779. />Update, after several months' use: The brush has an annoying design defect--the brushing mode is too easily reset inadvertently, and you can't tell which mode is selected except by cycling through all of the five modes so as to light the indicator LED.<br /><br
  2780. First was the brush head attachment, which unlike the Advance, is a single piece which is designed so that excess water that drips down the side of the brush can can be wiped off.
  2781. />I've read some of the negative reviews here, and feel as though if the buttons are getting in the way of your brushing, it means you are gripping the toothbrush handle way too tight.
  2782. />Given how much the unit and brush heads cost to buy and how little it costs the company to manufacture them overseas, you'd think it could get the rest to work.
  2783. It was high maintenance to keep it clean inside, and despite those efforts, periodically i would throw them away and get a new one because they became so nasty and i couldn't get my fingers into all the places where the gunk built up to clean it out.
  2784. charging stand is a little less sturdy than most but has two other places for brushed.
  2785. />It's a little strange at first, but you get used to the sensation.
  2786. They are sending me a new one, but in reading reviews I found that other people are on their third or fourth replacement.
  2787. One was a very early model Sonicare, the other two were Braun Oral-B models.
  2788. One thing that really made the difference for me is the fact that there is significantly less vibration that other products I've used so far.

All Reviews

  1. I believe everyone should use a sonic tooth brush. It cleans the teeth and gums really well. The vibration at first is weird, but after multiple uses you will adapt to it.
  2. Sonicare toothbrushes work very well. My teeth feel cleaner than they ever have with a traditional toothbrush. I bought one of these (Flexcare), and it lasted 3 years and 4 months.<br /><br />I had used the basic Elite series for a while, but the screw-in brushes got gross and smelly, so when the toothbrush died, I got the flex care. I like the snap on brush heads for these brushes. These are great brushes and do a great job cleaning, but I think they are too expensive and they include features I never used (and would bet most people don't use).<br /><br />When this one died, I decided to go with the most basic Sonicare toothbrush that had the quadpacer and this style of snap-on brush head. At the time of this review, that ends up being the Gum Health Sonicare, which is $80 vs. the Flexcare at $130. So far, I'm happy with the gum health toothbrush, but it's only been a week. It's not quite as sleek as the Flexcare, but given that I never used the advanced features of the Flexcare, I feel like I've made a smarter purchase this time around. We'll see how long it lasts though.
  3. This was supposed to be an improved model. The toothbrush section is improved because it is not longer open to a space to collect moisture and build up fungus, but the controls are too easily pressed and the function changed in the middle of brushing ones teeth.I would prefer having my old one, but after about 6 years the battery died and could not be replaced. That is another problem that also exisits in this newer one. I would not buy it and would send it back if I could.
  4. This is the only toothbrush I own. I have owned several through the years. I get the best results at my dentist<br />from this toothbrush. I can't live without it, and my grown children own them as well. It is the BEST toothbrush<br />on the market. Can't say enough about it. It is pricy but worth every penny. Just hang on to the receipt and if you have<br />any problems, Sonicare Customer Service is excellent. They are quick to replace your toothbrush if you have any<br />problems.

  8. This is our second Sonicare. The first one was bought about almost 3 years ago and it started to show signs of stress break (this is a common issue found by doing a search on the internet).   13. I would like to give this an outstanding review. It is comfortably designed, easy to use with automatic timer etc., leaves my mouth feeling clean and fresh, allows my teeth/gums to receive consistently good reviews from my dentist and dental hygienist, retains its charge through the week, and is convenient for travel as well as use at home. The only reservation is that the FlexCare toothbrush I purchased earlier stopped working after only 18 months. I regret its untimely demise. Definitely consider purchasing as it is a very good toothbrush. Just be sure to keep your receipt and warranty in a convenient location.

  19. I am ok with it as my 6-year old electric toothbrush (Sonicare too) finally gave up on me. I thought the one I just got would be 6 year technologically more advanced: great size indeed, the battery is a good as the old one: excellent duration: over 3 weeks between charges. When I insert the brush head, it doesn't go all the way to the bottom, a little gap stays in between it and the brush itself. I hope that's a glitch of the brush head and not of the body, otherwise, this will be a lemon.
  20. I upgraded from an Elite 7300 to this model and I am glad I did. The slimmer handle takes just a little getting used to if you are used to a bigger handle but I really like the streamlined feel to it. The toothbrush attachment is so easy to afix to the base and the toothbrush head itself seems to reach much better. There are several choices for cleaning, including shorter and longer brushing cycles as well as massage and gentle options. I am experimenting with all of them and the main button is easy to use and it is very simple once you get in the habit to select which option you want. If you like to stick with the same type of cleaning every day than it will do just that as well. The toothbrush is quieter than my old model and it really feels less abrasive even though it does a great job of cleaning.<br /><br />I did not buy the model that had the sanitizer because I knew I would never get around to using that part so I did not want to pay for a feature that I most likely would not use. With that said, the charger for just the toothbrush is fairly small and does not require lining up the toothbrush like some previous models. I am very happy with this toothbrush.
  21. This is easily the best toothbrush, manual or electric, that I have ever had. My dentist recommends that I brush without toothpaste for better cleaning using the two minute routine. Then I use the go care (1 min total) setting to bush with toothpaste. My teeth feel fresh and smooth overnight when I brush before bed. I need to follow a routine the next morning or I will forget to brush. Amazing machine.
  22. Everyone should use a sonicare...it cleans teeth and gums like nothing else. I will never go back to an ordinary toothbrush.
  23. The new sonicare toothbrush is very different from my well over 10 year old model. It works probably better than the older one. I was surprised that it was not sold with at least one more spare brush. Anyway, it does what it is supposed to do and seems easy to travel with.
  24. This toothbrush does an excellent job of teeth cleaning. However, it continues Phillips tradition of making poorly engineered parts that are non repairable and designed to fall apart so you have to buy new ones frequently. In my case, this toothbrush failed after about six months. When I went to take it apart to safely discard the environmentally polluting (read CHEAP) battery per instructions I found the failure was simply a screw falling out of the vibrating mechanism. Per Phillips instructions, the process of taking it apart to repair it or replace a battery is non recoverable (ie destructive). However, I was able to put the screw back and put it back together with some effort. In summary, using a non changeable poor quality battery and depending upon a screw to hold the vibrating mechanism together is such bad engineering it can't be anything but purposefully designed in obsolescence.[[ASIN:B0013TVEWA Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush]][[ASIN:B000UK2W4C Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer]]
  25. My daughter gave me a Sonicare toothbrush 8 years ago that I used until I \\"traded it in\\" for a newer model. The brush handle is slimmer, the recharger less bulky, the toothbrush head formed for easier manipulation on those back molars. The Sonicare brushes are essential to my good oral health. I appreciate the FlexCare options of the brush and use the different modes for different needs . Good choice for me to upgrade.
  26. To give you some context, I've owned two Sonicare toothbrushes and four Oral-B toothbrushes over the last 17 years, including the ever popular 3D/8850 and the \\"Triumph\\" 4000/5000/9000 (whatever number they've decided to use this year). I have never used the Oral-B sonic brush, mostly because it has mediocre reviews and requires different brush-heads anyway. If I'm going to invest in all new equipment, I might as well buy the one with 4.5 stars... I have found this particular Sonicare to be the best toothbrush I've ever used, and not necessarily for the reasons you might expect.<br /><br />First, what attracted me to Oral-B in the first place: it does a good job cleaning teeth and the standard brush-head is a very small, circular brush. I always found the enlarged brush-heads or cross-action brush-heads too gimicky, uncomfortable, and less effective. I would usually get 10 days to a charge, most brushes came with hard PLASTIC travel cases, which prevented them from being switched on inadvertently and discharging during the outbound flight of your vacation/business trip. In short, after 17 years of using several Oral-B brushes, I would consider myself a loyal customer.<br /><br />Cons of the last couple of Oral-B brushes can be found in the reviews I've written on the relevant pages, although it's hard to keep up since they keep switching model numbers to confuse the customer. Basically, there are three types still available: a very basic version that has the oldest style of charge and a chunky handle, a newer version with 40,000 revolutions per minute AND 3D back-and-forth motion (oscillation) AND the \\"Triumph,\\" which has the same specifications but an even chunkier handle to accommodate the LCD display. Either of the latter two are fine, although the charging circuit for my Triumph failed after barely a year, which is what made my mind up to switch to Sonicare.<br /><br />Pros of the Sonicare are manifold: it's smaller, lighter, quieter, simpler, can be had with \\"compact\\" or regular brush heads. The best feature for me is that it holds a charge for two full weeks, even though it's so much lighter. The weight may seem insignificant, but it all adds up when you travel on a daily basis. Then there's the results: my teeth are definitely cleaner. That absolutely surprised me, given how gung-ho I've been about Oral-B all these years. My teeth are smoother, whiter, and I've noticed that the red wine stains that usually affect my teeth between dental cleanings have disappeared, without the need for a dental cleaning. Is the difference huge? No, but it is noticeable, and it was a pleasant surprise.<br /><br />I thought the Sonicare and Oral-B would be very similar user experiences: both brushes have the little cut-outs every 30 seconds to remind you to change the set of teeth that you're currently brushing. It's not too intrusive and I've always liked it. This Sonicare completely cuts out after 2 minutes, unless you press the little button in advance to give you 3 minutes or 1 minute. I don't mind, since 2 minutes is all I ever shoot for (and you can always turn it right back on if you really need to). The battery indicator has 3 little levels, similar to the Triumph. So, objectively, they both clean teeth and have almost identical bells and whistles. Subjectively, they feel very different (different brushing motions) and have different results.<br /><br />So why not 5 stars? Well, this particular model came with a soft cloth travel case, which I fear will lead to discharging (first trip with it is scheduled for next week - I'll be bringing the included compact charger with me). Also, I can't get to the very back of my teeth quite as easily as I could with the small circular Oral-B brush.<br /><br />To Oral-B, I would say you just lost a customer because you couldn't be bothered to update your brushes with Lithium Ion batteries. To everyone else, I'd say if you're choosing between the two, the latest Sonicare brushes beat Oral-B on every dimension..
  27. works mechanically great, but the brushes are very stiff and even when you buy &#34;their&#34; soft ones, they are still too stiff for sensitive gums.
  28. I got this toothbrush right at a year ago when I learned that excessive crunching and sawing with my manual toothbrush had resulted in my need for a $1,100 torture procedure a.k.a a gum graft. My new periodontist swore by the Philips and said that he'd been using one for 15 years.<br /><br />So I bought the FlexCare because I liked the idea of the sensitive setting. At first everything went well. Then, I too, encountered the vibrating brush head that wobbles off when I first changed to a new brush head. I thought the head was defective, like many other people, and went through a couple packs of expensive heads before getting a pack that seemed to stay on properly.<br /><br />Then about 2 weeks ago, out of the blue the brush began to turn itself on! This happened in the middle of the night two different times. Talk about a way to be woken up in the night! This thing just going off, rattling across the bathroom counter. We'd press the off button and sometimes it would stay off and other times it'd cut back on 10-15 minutes later. I left it off the charger so that the battery would run down all the way. Once that happened, it would not re-charge. If I put it on the charger, I can hear a slight humming noise and see what looks like little sparks behind where the green light should be glowing. My husband told me to take it off the charger before I set the bathroom on fire.<br /><br />I also agree the the control buttons are poorly located. I was forever hitting one while in the middle of brushing.<br /><br />So, now I don't know what to do. All the reviews about Customer Service make me not-so-excited to try to send it back. On the flip side, I was told that the use of the brush was helping my gums and if I kept it up, hopefully I would never need another graft (the most painful thing EVER)
  29. If it wasn't for the fact that the shaft broke with even the smallest of drops, I would give this product five stars. Some might think that isn't fair, but at $120+, and no warning label of its' fragile shaft, it deserves one star. Go with the Oral-B brushes with a floss action head- comparable clean, without the egg shell shaft.
  30. This toothbrush is too complicated. it's as if Sonicare was trying too hard to add features that the toothbrush simply doesn't need. I'm actually considering going back to my previous Sonicare Elite. If you have to read the instruction manual more than once (or even at all) I say it's not worth it.
  31. For a long time, I was hesitant to shell out the $100+ to invest in an electric toothbrush, but after some heavy pressure from my dentist, I decided to buy this one. I'm completely glad I did. I've been using it for about two months now, it's been at least 3 months since my last cleaning, and my teeth still feel like I'd had them cleaned yesterday.<br /><br />I have sensitive teeth, and the standard mode is a little too intense for my teeth to use regularly, so I use the sensitive mode. I haven't had any problems or discomfort with that, and as I said, my teeth feel amazingly clean, so I don't think the performance suffers at all from using a less-intense brushing mode.
  32. I bought this toothbrush as a replacement for the last Sonicare toothbrush that I left behind in a hotel room. I've been using this product for over two years and I love it. It has several options for different cleanings, even a sensitive setting, and it is easy to use. It is timed for two minutes so you get a full brushing. It even has a setting for a quick brushing that lasts for one minute instead of the usual two minutes. It has a nice little interrupting vibration to let you know when to switch quadrants of your mouth. Using this toothbrush leaves your teeth with the same feeling as having your dentist performing a cleaning. It will take a little getting used to at first, but it is worth it.<br /><br />The battery stays charged for weeks and the travel charger is pretty compact. The full charging takes about 12-15 hours. The battery indicator is pretty accurate and will let you know when you need to charge it. Even on the lowest level and it turning orange, I still get another 2-3 days of brushing out of it. The replacement brushes run about $20 for three. But those can last 2-3 months each.
  33. I had a two year old Sonicare that I fried when I took it to Europe. I am so glad the new Sonicare handles both currents now without a transformer. I really like the new design. I feel my teeth get cleaner because I can reach all my teeth better, plus I feel it vibrates more for a better clean. It is also much easier to keep clean.
  34. I bought this same tooth brush from Amazon back in 2009 in a set for my wife & Myself which is the Flexcare Deluxe Edition set, it comes with 2 of the RS 950 body's 4 brush heads two chargers and one ultraviolet head cleaner which is a great deal. This system really gets your teeth super clean. One word of warning, If you constantly remove the brush head from the body everyday to place it in the ultraviolet cleaner the tip on the main body where the brush head attaches will loosen and pull out of its socket and render it useless, which is what happen to my wife's (After 3 Years Of Use) the other day which is why I just ordered this replacement. I use the travel charger and only remove the brush head when it needs replacing and clean it by turning it on and running it under running water. We love our Sonicares and I would another for myself tomorrow if mine broke.

  42. Prior to buying this toothbrush I had used the battery-powered Crest SpinBrush for several years, and while it cleaned my teeth much better than a manual brush, I was always frustrated with its bulky brush head (I have a small mouth) and grew tired of the ebb-and-flow of the batteries: working great at full power and pitifully weak towards the end of their life.<br /><br />Enter the Sonicare FlexCare toothbrush, with its small brush head and built in rechargeable battery. At first, the sonic vibration took some getting used to, and I had to learn to turn it off before removing it from my mouth to avoid getting spray everywhere. The only thing that still bothers me is the buzz I get if the plastic part of the head touches my teeth (I try to avoid it, but it still happens from time to time).<br /><br />As for the performance, it cleans wonderfully and in less time that the SpinBrush did, and it's easier to reach my back molars with the small brush head. I don't use the timers or brushing routines (the timer alarm was easy enough to turn off, but the brush still automatically turns off after two minutes, which is mildly annoying), however, I do occasionally use the 'Massage' setting. I love the fact that the Sonicare retains the same level of power, even when the battery is only at 25%, and it's ultra-easy to charge.<br /><br />Overall, I'm very pleased with the Sonicare, and highly recommend it!
  43. This is a great toothbrush. This is my third Sonicare purchase in 8 years and I can't imagine using anything else!
  44. Much better than the previous version. It is really nice that the batteries can be replaced. I also like the smaller, pop-off brush head. Eliminates saliva and gunk from accumulating in the screw top. It keeps the unit as a whole cleaner. The smaller charger and travel case are much easier to pack for trips as well. The unique charger design that allows the cord to be stored inside is a very nice touch. The additional brush modes are nice to have, although I don't really ever see a use for the \\"massage\\" mode. The quick clean is nice when you don't have time for the full 2 minute brush cycle.
  45. This was recommended to my daughter by her orthodontist. It has worked very well for her in keeping her teeth really clean and healthy with having braces on. There is even a massaging mode to stimulate the area around the gum where it is difficult to clean if you have brackets on your molars. Good luck and happy brushing!
  46. I was forced to purchase a new Sonicare toothbrush after my previous one died. I was going to look around for a different brand since I was kind of upset it died 30 days after my warranty ended, but immediately found that I am way too attached to my Sonicare. I looked around and found this one on Amazon (after a lot of searching) and have to say that it was a GREAT buy! The issues that I found in my previous Sonicare were fixed in this version (including the use of magnets which made a mess inside the brush head's base). I swear by Sonicare toothbrushes and I honestly feel naked without it. My teeth feel unbelievably clean! A very worthwhile purchase.<br /><br />Update (10/27/13): It's been over 3 years since I have purchased this and it's still going strong! Just make sure that you *DO NOT* leave this thing on the charger at all times and you shouldn't have any problems with the internal battery. I only charge mine when it is blinking yellow (telling me to charge it), and the battery still lasts between 1.5 and 2 weeks!<br /><br />Update (5/30/14): Still going strong! The battery still lasts about 1 1/2 - 2 weeks before needing to charge it overnight. As stated in my previous update, only charge it when it blinks yellow and the battery should last a long time.
  47. Prior to acquiring this model, I had over a year's experience with the Philips Sonicare Elite toothbrush, which I was using on my dentist's recommendation (and, frankly, after a fair amount of dental work). I needed something that would provide good brushing and I found the basic principles of the Sonicare system to be helpful, so I understood the system and what it could do.<br /><br />This FlexCare model, however, is a big step up over the Elite series. This is less cumbersome and has some very useful (and easy) choices in modes of operation: it even has a \\"Go Care\\" 1-minute quickie routine if you're pressed for time. The charger, if reduced to its travel mode, is very small and it, and the brush/handle assembly, are very compact, much more so than the Elite. The \\"beep\\" that signals the time the user spends on each quadrant of his/her teeth is clever and means you will be spending the right amount of time on your teeth.<br /><br />The toothbrush is cheaper to replace, is a lot simpler (the Elite toothbrush includes much of the mechanism) and, if more than one person uses Sonicare, means that you need have only one handle, a considerable savings as we've found the older Elite really needs one handle per user because of the clunky nature of the screw-on toothbrush. The FlexCare toothbrush is much smaller, has a nice series of colored rubber gaskets to distinguish one from another, and snaps on and off easily.<br /><br />One point to stress that the manual does not: the Sonicare system really does need a light touch on the handle -- like holding a flute -- to save wear on the brushes. And a light touch is all that's needed, a lot better than using a manual toothbrush with too much force. Given the fact that dental work is costly, this toothbrush may save far more than you'd think. Highly recommend.
  48. I'd used Sonicare products in the past at the advice of pretty much every dentist who ever looked at my bad gums. My old Sonicare would no longer take a charge (little did I know that the battery could be replaced), and I tossed it. Fast forward to a few months back when my hygienist recommended this new and improved Sonicare to me (at which point I found out about the old battery in my previous one). I bought it right there at the dentist office, started using it, and when I went back 3 months later, my gums were noticeably in much better shape.<br /><br />It's easy to use, effective, makes my teeth feel super clean, is idiot proof for proper dental and gum care, and I have no complaints aside from cost and then the cost of replacement heads (though the 3 pack for $25 here on Amazon is a better deal than I've seen in stores). My gums are worth it.
  49. After seeing some of the preliminary reviews, I was excited to try this. I had an electronic toothbrush, probably about 10 years ago, and I stopped using it for some reason I can't remember. I think that was a Braun. Since then, I've bought a couple of Crest spin brushes. I used to think they were all pretty much the same, but the Sonicare is in a whole different league. Besides the superior cleaning you get with the sonic action, my favorite parts are the timer that tells you how long to brush in one area and the different modes. I like the massage mode but will use the clean mode for daily use. Since I hadn't used an electric toothbrush for a while, I used the Easy Start mode, and that was nice, but I think most people can probably handle jumping right in to clean mode. I also find the brush to be comfortable in my hand. This product is highly recommended!
  50. I have owned the 2 prior models of this brush. Although not all of the updates are great, most of them are. No more obnoxious gunk between the brush head and the handle! The charger is better designed and easier to keep clean. The battery seems to last forever, even when the indicator lights claim there isn't much power left. Most importantly, the brush leaves you with a cleaner and cleaner feeling mouth and than before.<br /><br />I have no regrets upgrading to this brush from the Sonicare Elite. It is arguably the best consumer dental hygiene product available. I recommend it.
  51. I love this new brush, cleans very well. however i only paid 119.00 for mine at the dentist office and it came with 2 brush heads compared to the one at amazon
  52. Lightweight, small, easy to use, recharges quickly, I like the \\"massage\\" feature, it feels quite different from the normal vibration. My teeth feel smooth and clean when I'm finished. I believe it is far superior to my previous rotating head toothbrush. I also like the fact that if you accidently hit the On/Off switch in the middle of a brushing sequence, when you press the switch again, it will continue from where you were in the brush cycle rather than restarting from the beginning of the cycle. Pricey, but worth it in my opinion.
  53. I upgraded from an Oral-B. Several friends recommended Sonicare, so I gave it a try. This model is definitely much slimmer and quieter than the Elite series, which was selling point for me. The extra brushing modes are extras, and really weren't that important. I'm hoping it lives up to the marketing and that my next visit to the dentist is much shorter! I did a full charge up and down on the battery, and so far it lasts more than a week between charging...good news for vacation!

  55. I've used Sonicare at my dentist's recommendation since they first came out. Spending the extra money on the Flexcare was well worth the investment. I especially like the smaller brush head and the additional timing features.
  56. This is my 3rd Sonicare toothbrush, and I've been a big fan so far. I bought this one because my existing model had the problem with stuff building up inside the brush head and it was very hard to clean out.<br /><br />I agree with all the positive reviews as far as the improved design, lighter weight, more options, and it's much easier to keep clean than the previous model. However, the metal shaft on mine came loose within a few months and got so bad that I finally called Norelco for service. I gave them the model number and serial number and they immediately offered to send a free replacement, with a postage-free box in which to return my broken one. That was over two weeks ago, and it hasn't arrived yet. I phoned back a couple days ago and was told it was on back-order and should arrive within a few more days.<br /><br />The service representative was friendly and I didn't have to wait long on the phone, but I have noticed that several other reviewers here on Amazon have had the same problem I have had. I'm wondering how long my replacement will last.<br /><br />So, when it worked, it was excellent, but it should not have broken so fast and the replacement shouldn't take so long to be shipped from Norelco. Meanwhile, I'm using my old model which I'm glad I didn't throw away. It still works fine after more than two years.<br /><br />Edit, one week later: I just phoned the company again because after 3 weeks, I have still not received my replacement. I was told that the toothbrush is still on back-order and mine hasn't been shipped yet. They have no idea how long it will be, though they agreed that it shouldn't take as long as it has. I was also told that this model has had issues with the metal shaft \\"dislodging\\", which is what mine did. So, be warned that there is a known issue, and that in spite of the warranty, you may end up waiting a while for your replacement if you get a bad one. In Norelco's favor, all of the phone representatives I've spoken with have been polite and helpful, but unfortunately, there's nothing they can do to speed up the process. I'm not ready to say I'd never buy another Sonicare, but I will certainly look at the competition when I get my next toothbrush. This is just bad PR and bad product support from Norelco, which amounts to very bad business practice, especially during a recession. Are there really that many people shelling out $130+ for a toothbrush right now?helpful, but unfortunately, there's nothing they can do to speed up the process. I'm not ready to say I'd never buy another Sonicare, but I will certainly look at the competition when I get my next toothbrush. This is just bad PR and bad product support from Norelco, which amounts to very bad business practice, especially during a recession.   58. Unbelievable quality and precision toothbrush. You only think you are bushing your teeth with anything else.
  59. I had the Oral-B prior to buying this product, and if you're choosing between them, don't hesitate a moment to purchase the Phillips Sonicare instead. It's far superior.<br /><br />The Oral-B has a small round rotating brush. It's hard to get enough toothpaste on the brush, it doesn't rotate very fast, and it has a mechanical head, which means that water and gunk can make it's way into the body of the toothbrush. I actually went back to a regular brush and threw out the Oral-B.<br /><br />The Sonicare however (this product,) is the best toothbrush bar none that I've ever owned. The charger doesn't get dirty because it charges inductively, so there are no electric contacts to get dirty, and the brush head vibrates magnetically with no mechanical connection, so gunk doesn't get into the body of the Sonicare. To clean it you just pop the brush head off and rinse. Both ends of the Sonicare are sealed. Brilliant!<br /><br />The other things I like about the Sonicare are that you can set it at two speeds, the brush head is small so it's easy to brush my wisdom teeth without gagging, and the head vibrates very fast, unlike the Oral-B. It runs a very long time on a charge, too, so if you're going on a two week trip you won't have to bother bringing the charger. It will probably last a month on a charge, in fact. But it's best not to discharge a rechargeable battery too deeply, for long life. Especially because the battery is sealed inside the body. It also has a charge indicator, so I recharge it after it's gone down one bar on the indicator.
  60. I've been using electric toothbrushes for more than a decade and finally found the one I like. I started with the round heads from OralB and they were ok, but then the sonicare technology picked my curiosity.<br />The price for Sonicare was ridiculous (still is) but eventually I found a justification to get it. Loved the actual brushing but I didn't get this model, nooooo back then the best I could get was one of the Essence model. Why?, why do these people have the brains to create a magnificent tool that cuts the cleaning at the dentist chair in more than 60% but make that ridiculous brush head. The head on the \\"Essence\\" model is an invitation for germs and cruddiness.<br />OralB has a nice, easy to keep clean brush head, why re-invent the wheel?. Fortunately Sonicare saw the light and came out with this FlexCare model that (similar to OralB)allows the user to keep the underside of the brush heads clean.<br /><br />The toothbrush work great. Brushing the same times a day I used to with other brushes my cleanings at the dentist are no longer a nightmare. I sit, they look all over and just compliment me on the lack of tar or any build up, the process takes about the same it takes the strong cycle on my regular morning brush.

  63. I read over many of the reviews for both this version of the Sonicare, as well as the version that comes with the UV sanitizer.. My hygienist strongly recommend either the FlexCare or an Oral-B Complete.. Most helpful with this recommendation was the fact that my dentist's office does not sell any of these products, so I felt I was getting an unbiased recommendation. Unfortunately for me, that left me to deciding between the two. I opted for the Sonicare, since I have had two Oral-B products in the past, and neither one impressed me. Also, I decided for the version without the UV sanitizer. The specific model I purchased was the FlexCare+ HX6922/03, which I believe is the most current version of this.<br /><br />The toothbrush does a fantastic job of cleaning your teeth. After you are done, your teeth really do feel much cleaner, and the Sonicare does a very thorough job. One thing I should note -- I did not purchase mine from Amazon -- instead, I went with a discount online toothbrush retailer, which sold it for $95. Therefore, the contents of my box may differ from what is offered here...The model I purchased says 'Professional' at the bottom of the box, and from what I understand, this may be the version that is sold in dental offices. It comes with the toothbrush, 2 ProResults brush heads (1 compact & 1 standard), 1 Deluxe charger with cord wrap and brush head storage, 2 travel caps, and 1 hard travel case. Additionally, the model I purchased has 5 cleaning modes: Clean (standard 2 minute clean), Gum Care (2 minute clean, followed by 1 minute for getting back to problem areas), Refresh (1 minute 'quick' clean), Sensitive (2 minutes, reduced speed for sensitive teeth/gums), and Massage (for stimulating gums). I use the 'Clean' mode exclusively, and it works quite well.<br /><br />As others have mentioned, it is important that you do not power on the toothbrush until it is in your mouth. Failing to do so will result in toothpaste all over. BUT, if youve used electric toothbrushes before, you should already know this.. Also, don't remove it from your mouth while its on, or you'll experience the same issue. One of the things that bothers me slightly is that occasionally I will hit the shaft of the brush head against one of my teeth, and its not the most pleasant experience -- it doesnt hurt, its just annoying when it happens.<br /><br />I wanted to post this review to bring up two things that have been mentioned in many of the reviews I have read that Philips seems to have fixed:<br /><br />1) Changing the mode while brushing -- many people posted that it was possible (and very easy) to inadvertently change the mode while brushing due to the fact that the mode button is right near where your hand would be holding the brush. On the model that I purchased, you cannot change the mode while the brush is on -- you must power it off first, fixing that first problem.<br /><br />2) Remembering the previous mode used -- while I use the 'Clean' mode exclusively, other reviewers complained that the unit should remember the last mode used. Some people prefer to use the 'Sensitive' mode all the time, and found it annoying to have to change to their preferred mode everytime they used the toothbrush. This problem appears to be corrected also. Each time I have started the toothbrush, it has been in the mode that was last used -- not 'Clean'.<br /><br />Overall, the product is excellent and is a good investment for anyone that is aiming to improve their dental health. I will update this review in a few months to let people know how it works out in the long run.ric toothbrushes before, you should already know this.. Also, don't remove it from your mouth while its on, or you'll experience the same issue. One of the things that bothers me slightly is that occasionally I will hit the shaft of the brush head against one of my teeth, and its not the most pleasant experience -- it doesnt hurt, its just annoying when it happens. I wanted to post this review to bring up two things that have been mentioned in many of the reviews I have read that Philips seems to have fixed: 1) Changing the mode while brushing -- many people posted that it was possible (and very easy) to inadvertently change the mode while brushing due to the fact that the mode button is right near where your hand would be holding the brush. On the model that I purchased, you cannot change the mode while the brush is on -- you must power it off first, fixing that first problem. 2) Remembering the previous mode used -- while I use the 'Clean' mode exclusively, other reviewers complained that the unit should remember the last mode used. Some people prefer to use the 'Sensitive' mode all the time, and found it annoying to have to change to their preferred mode everytime they used the toothbrush. This problem appears to be corrected also. Each time I have started the toothbrush, it has been in the mode that was last used -- not 'Clean'. Overall, the product is excellent and is a good investment for anyone that is aiming to improve their dental health. I will update this review in a few months to let people know how it works out in the long run.
  64. OK, so I've never written an Amazon review before, but I really just had to write one for this amazing little device.<br /><br />I'm not a big tooth-brusher, I must admit - I tend to procrastinate more than I should, but I am LOVING this new FlexCare toothbrush. It's so fun and easy to use, I'm finding I want to brush my teeth 3 or 4 times a day (but restraining myself)!<br /><br />It's really not even like brushing - it just seems to blast the dirt off my teeth. I honestly believe they're already whiter after just two days.<br /><br />The timer is awesome - 2 minutes broken into 4 30-second quadrants - and really appeals to my engineering mind, since I know exactly how long each session will last.<br /><br />I really don't think the brush needs all those complicated modes - just my own opinion.<br /><br />I've recently begun purchasing very high quality items that will (hopefully) last a long time, work great, and just make me feel like the wealthiest guy in the world. I started with cooking equipment (butcher knife, bamboo cutting board), and now count this toothbrush as one of those purchases.<br /><br />A $125 toothbrush?!!<br /><br />Absolutely.<br /><br />In fact, it's close to if not the best toothbrush you can buy - you and your dentist will be amazed at the results.
  65. This product is the best electric toothbrush on the market.   67. A friend convinced me to try an electric toothbrush insisting that I would fall instantly in love with it. Unfortunately that wasn't the case. The toothbrush is great and I've had no problems with it but it takes some getting used to if you've never used one before. You have to be more aware of how you're brushing and what you're doing. I can't tell you how many times I've taken the toothbrush out of my mouth while brushing to either spit or get a better angle and the next thing you know toothpaste is spattered all over your bathroom mirror because it vibrates like crazy. It was funny the first couple of times but it just got annoying. Now that I've been using it for a few weeks and I've adapted to the quirks I actually enjoy it. My mouth and teeth definitely do feel cleaner and more fresh using this brush, especially if you try to go back to old school brushing after using it consistently even just a few days. My favorite feature is the timer that lets you know when to change brushing areas. I haven't really used many of the other features like the gum massage setting because it kinda creeps me out a little. Anyway long story short... or long... it took me awhile to adjust to the new brush but now I find myself not wanting to be without it.

  87. My dentist recommended this toothbrush so I purchased it about a year ago. So far I've had no problems with the day to day functionality of the toothbrush, and I like that it has several brushing cycles to choose from. I especially like the \\"Go Care\\" brushing cycle for mornings or for when I'm short on time. Though the length of this cycle is shorter, it still leaves my teeth feeling really clean.<br /><br />The reason I'm not giving the toothbrush 5 stars is because, although it's slim, easy to hold, and easy to brush with, the placement of the main control button on the brush could be better. The button is unfortunately located right where you tend to hold the brush when brushing your teeth, so I have occasionally accidentally turned the brush off mid-cycle. Phillips must have anticipated this tendency because if you accidentally turn the brush off mid-cycle and then you immediately turn the brush back on, the brushing cycle picks up right where it left off.<br /><br />The toothbrush comes with a pedestal (which is also the charger)and two pegs to hold extra toothbrush heads. I have found that unless you completely dry off your toothbrush, a ring will form on the pedestal in the spot where your toothbrush sits. I've also noticed that grime can accumulate in the crease of the rubber base of the toothbrush. I'm kind of a neat freak so this annoys me, but it's pretty minimal and you may not even notice.<br /><br />Overall, the Sonicare FlexCare is an efficient and effective toothbrush that keeps my teeth squeaky clean.

  91. If you are looking for an excellent electric toothbrush that will make your dental hygienist happy....look no further. This is it.<br /><br />This \\"kit\\" contains:<br />1 Sonicare Flexcare rechargeable toothbrush handle which is the \\"business\\" part of the tooth brush.<br />1 ProResults brush head that fits on to the handle. This brush should be replaced every three or so months.<br />1 Smallish (3.5\\" x 3\\") multi-voltage \\"deluxe\\" travel charger with \\"cord wrap\\" and \\"brush head storage\\" (two tiny pins on the back hold extra brushes, should you have them...yippee!)<br />1 \\"Hygienic travel cap\\" which is a clear plastic \\"dust\\" cap that fits over the brush when not in use.<br />1 \\"Luxury soft travel case\\" which is a cheap plastic fold over case with a \\"Phillips\\" label on the front. This case will only hold the toothbrush, not the charger so if you are taking a trip the poor little multi-voltage charger goes without it's own case.<br /><br />Sonicare makes several toothbrush models. FlexCare is a good choice because it allows the user to select three brushing modes: regular, sensitive, or massage. These three modes operate for two minutes each. There are also two additional pre programmed brushing time routines: the \\"Go Care\\" which is a one minute routine for the person with poor-to-fair dental habits and the three minute \\"Max Care\\" combined clean and massage cycle for the truly obsessive-compulsive.<br /><br />Are these timers really necessary? No, absolutely not! Are they helpful? Yes! I admit to cheating on my brush time. Having a little buzzer going off every 30 seconds is a helpful reminder to switch to the next quadrant before my sleep befuddled head hits the medicine cabinet.<br /><br />Another nice feature is a battery life gauge which lets you know when its time to recharge, should you be the kind of person who does not store the brush on the charger when not in use.<br /><br />The charge on these brushes lasts a long time. In fact, you can travel with just the brush handle for up to a week with out the need for the charger.<br /><br />My household has been using these brushes for a while now. We have the FlexCare model that comes with two handles and a UV sanitizer charger base and a travel base. The reason for purchasing this new single unit is that someone (who shall go unnamed) tried to replace the brush and somehow, someway bent the metal pin attachment on the end of the handle. I have no idea how this happened because this metal pin is in no way fragile....but there you have it! Unfortunately, Phillips does not sell just the handle, you have to purchase the entire new kit and this kit is the least expensive one available.sh handle for up to a week with out the need for the charger.<br /><br />My household has been using these brushes for a while now. Luckily, the first time it happend It was under the warranty and they replaced it with no problems. When I called about this one they bascially said i'm out of luck. The new toothbrush did not come with a seperate warranty and they would be more than happy to send me a $10 rebate to purchase another one.
  100. This is my second Philips Sonicare toothbrush. What surprised me was the fact that now they only give you one brush instead of two like my last one. The plastic mold in the box still has a space for two but one is now empty. If they are going to short you one brush, at least change the molding so it's not so obvious you're getting stiffed.
  101. This toothbrush has improved my gum health dramatically, as a dentist I take very good care of my teeth, brushing with a manual toothbrush is ok, but brushing with the Sonicare Flexcare you receive the benefit you would from a prophylaxis from your dental hygienist (minus the scaling and probing). This is especially good for people who don't floss, I'm not saying not to floss but the people who refuse to, it does a good job getting in the interproximals like floss would but again is no substitute for floss. I would recommend this toothbrush to my patients any day and I do. I sell this toothbrush at my office. It sells out almost weekly. Worth the price in my opinion!

  105. I got this toothbrush on the advice of a friend who was studying in Dental School at the time. I was reluctant to try electric toothbrushes because I thought they were for lazy people. I had broken my right thumb at a ball game, several years ago, and while my hand was in a cast, I used one of the cheaper AAA battery powered, rotating brush. That experience was a disappointment so I went back to my regular brush when the cast was gone. But Sonicare is truly is a fantastic cleaning machine and leaves the mouth feeling almost as clean as after a dental visit. I have now owned and used it for over two years. Still runs beautifully although battery life may have gone down a bit. I've read reviews that suggest that this may be the best toothbrush out there (Although if you are buying now, check out the newer Flexcare+ model, which has a better carrying case) I prefer the slim design of the Flexcare than the fatter models from both Philipps and Oral-B. Also I read a review that said the Elite model's refills can have stuff growing inside them unless you clean it regularly. A lesser problem on this brush. I like both the 1-minute and 3-minute modes on this, but both I and my hygienist wish they had a 2-minute option. The only drawback I see in Sonic toothbrushes is that they are a bit loud in the mouth, and some days when I am half asleep or it is late night, I don't want so much ruckus in my mouth, and I choose the regular brush. Vibration causes noise and your ears are right there. Philips can't fight Physics, so don't hold it against them. While traveling, this is a much heavier toothbrush to carry, so on some trips I take the regular brush. However, if the trip is longer than seven days, I immediately notice the drop in dental hygiene. This has become a necessity. I highly recommend it.
  106. The same week I order the Sonicare FlexCare I had scheduled my semiannual cleaning. My dental hygienist highly recommended this cleaning system without knowing I had already order it! She explained the technique for using the Sonicare and what she liked best about her FlexCare brush. I could not be more pleased! While some may consider the price point high, I believe it is worth every penny!!

  111. Does a great job cleaning your teeth. Another strength is that the battery lasts forever after being charged. Unit looks great as well.<br /><br />But the toothbrush is connected to the handle with a tiny metal piece which after 18 months stopped fitting into it's slot - and thus caused the unit to stop being useful.
  112. The Philips Sonicare toothbrush range utilises ultrasonic cleaning (as used in hospital sterile service units to clean the gunk off surgical instruments) in addition to the physical vibration of the bristles on the teeth. You don't need to move or agitate the brush: just hold it to the teeth upper, lower, left, right, inside, outside then rinse when finished. A timer is incorporated which issues an audible signal every 30 seconds, repeated four times to ensure upper left, upper right, lower left and lower right areas are cleaned properly.<br /><br />We've had other makes of electric toothbrush in the past which use the word \\"sonic\\" in the product description but few actually employ genuine ultrasonic cleaning technology like these from Philips (the Oral B range also uses genuine ultrasonic cleaning).<br /><br />The heads are removable for transportation and may be changed or renewed regularly, and in our case there have been no issues with the head working loose as reported by a minority of reviewers here. If you have two toothbrushes in the bathroom, the handles come colour-coded so you don't get mixed up. However if you do have two brushes, an irritating minor issue will soon become evident.<br /><br />The instructions for use insist the toothbrushes should be kept on the charging base (a clever device which works well and only exposes sealed plastic to sealed plastic, so is effectively waterproof). However keeping both brushes on the charging base is simply not possible as no twin charger is available, so if you have two brushes then they have to be charged alternately. Almost no bathroom is fitted with more than one electric razor/toothbrush power socket, so buying two separate chargers will not solve this problem. This is a minor design fault, as mentioned by another reviewer, which quickly becomes obvious (and slightly irksome) to the new user.<br /><br />Another consideration is that these are almost the most expensive electric toothbrushes on the market, but worth it if you value good dental hygiene. Again, in our case they have proved to be 100% reliable in service so over time the initial outlay evens out.dental hygiene. Again, in our case they have proved to be 100% reliable in service so over time the initial outlay evens out.
  113. I've only had my new Sonicare Flexcare system for one week, and am still in the initial \\"set-up stage\\". Can tell the difference in the cleanliness of my teeth when I brush as compared to the Braun I've used for the past 15 years. The only disappointment for me is that my husband can't use it. I don't really notice the vibration when it's running, but he made his living as a welder and his wrist and hand can not stand to hold on to the unit--too painful to use. So now we have a Sonicare and a Braun in our bathroom. If there was not a noticable difference between the two I would sent the Sonicare back, however there really is a difference between the two systems. Also the compact brush works very well in my mouth because it is small and allows me to brush back behind the molars. If you are considering a purchse I really think it is a quality investment in your dental hygiene and you really do not have anything to loose, as Sonicare has a 28 day return policy if not 100% satisfied with the purchase.
  114. Feels just it like it should - amazing. This thing buzzes and buffs your whites to a shine. No more nasty tarter buildup for your dentist to shake his finger at. Seriously, it's good at breaking that stuff up, especially on those rear molars. I imagine their slogan could be \\"once you go sonicare.... \\" you know.
  115. We bought the SonicCare Flexcare in 2008. Within 8 months my husband's toothbrush broke. It just died, it would not turn on. Customer service said that we must always have the unit on the charger, which we were not doing. So a new toothbrush was sent out to us. Which was great. Then 4 months later my sonic care broke. I always had it on the charger as customer service told us, but that didn't stop mine from vibrating strangely and stopping after a few seconds. So once again we called customer service and after following their steps and still unable to get the toothbrush to work properly we got a new one in the mail and returned the old one. So this happens 2 more times. In all we are on our 4th replacement. The 2 year warranty expired so we can't get a replacement. This is the worst Sonic Care. We never dropped it we never traveled with them, they just sat on the chargers as advised by customer sevice. I don't understand how there is an average of 4 1/2 stars. My old sonic care, the heavy clunky one lasted 6 years, these barely make it through 8 months. I wish I could say we got a lemon, but 4 in a row? That's just not logical. Customer service is great, so at least we got 2 years out of the 100+ we spent on the set.
  116. I have used electric toothbrushes for several years, since having received a recommendation from my dentist (who is probably getting some kick-back from Sonicare, but I still like him since he takes care of my five crowns which I have received as a result of a childhood injury). The previous toothbrushes have lasted 2+ years easily before the electric/magnetic motor broke. This toothbrush after 5 months has started to turn itself on randomly at night (such that it now sleeps in a closet with the door closed and a couple pillows on it to muffle the noise. I don't know how long I can take it, but the thing should be under warranty,of course the Philips warranty web site is currently down (or maybe it's alwasy down?!).<br /><br />My advice is, save your money, use a floss regularly, don't drink too much alcohol, stop smoking and use a regular, soft head toothbrush, you will probably be just as well off and you will not have to worry about the electronic pandemonium that could ensue.   129. I have been reading others on here relating this product to other \\"ordinary\\" powered tooth brushes. The reason this one is on the high end of the price spectrum, is the fact that it uses the same technology your dentist uses to remove plaque. Ultra-sonic waves, that blast plaque, and help disperse it, which is the entire point of brushing your teeth. Other models can not compete at plaque removal if they are not using these ultra-sonic technologies.<br /><br />Now anyone that has ever been to a dentist, and had a cleaning with what seemed like a water pick, instead of the regular sickle type, pain makers, knows the difference between the two. And there is no faster, more effective way than to combine that sonic/water sickle, which we can not get for home use.<br /><br />This is the next BEST thing. Ask your dentist on your next check up. I don't buy all the hype about the different models, they all effectively do the same thing, just with a different face and a jazzy name. Any of the sonicare brush sets will do.

The sonic part of the brush really does work. After you finish the brushing your mouth really feels clean and that feeling lasts for a long time. I had some tough roast beef get stuck between my teeth and the sonic part dislodged it in a flash. I don't need tooth picks any more. Again more people out of work.<br /><br />Mechanically, it is rugged, well designed and built. Thus far, I have had no problem with it. The control button are easy to use and the LED lights are easy to see and I have no problem seeing which cycle I am using. It is very easy to keep clean by wiping the handle portion with a cloth and removing the brush portion and rinsing. Eventhough, the electrical part of the toothbrush appears to be well sealed I am careful not to get that part soaking wet. I purchased replacement brushes from Amazon.com as well.   139. This Sonicare flexcare is my first sonic toothbrush. I thought the spinbrush was really a big step up from a manual brush but the sonicare is way better. Within a couple of weeks I noticed my teeth and gums had a huge improvement and some stubborn stains were improved as well.<br /><br />BUT the way the heads are shaped with a dramatic arch it seems the designers only had the front of the teeth in mind & I found there is plaque build up behind my lower front teeth that is from not being able to sufficiently apply the bristles to that area (short of holding the brush at a 90 degree angle upward and leaving my mouth open while spittle spews onto the mirror and down my shirt, which makes the dramatically long front upper bristles pummel the soft under-the-tongue tissue). Flossing nightly has not prevented this since one can not wrap the floss around the entire bottom of each tooth (thus the importance of a brush such as Sonicare!) I'm going to start using a manual toothbrush in that area and buy some plaque remover, now that I see what a problem it's become.<br /><br />I still recommend this item for the overall health of gums and teeth but this is a big problem for me and hopefully I can warn others so they don't suddenly realize that the plaque has built up.<br /><br />(Also just a note, if you are searching toothbrushes because of a film in your mouth or constant bad breath, I recommend researching Candidas Albacans because these could be symptoms of bacteria overgrowth from overuse of sugars and starches in your diet, a very under-diagnosed illness.)
  140. This toothbrush is far better than any I have ever used. I cleans my teeth so well that they feel like I have just come from the Hygenist. I was slow to spend the extra money but it was well worth it!
  141. My whole life I've been a dentist's dream come true. I couldn't imagine I'd ever go to the dentist and have less than 4 cavities -- usually more like 6 or 8 with a root canal and crown thrown in for good measure. Every time I'm lectured about how I need to quit drinking pop. Well, to be honest drinking pop is one of my 4 fundamental reasons for living, not gonna happen folks. I got this device at COST from my periodontist, on a whim, and now after 8 months of flossing every-other-day and using my Sonicare 1.75 times a day (trying for 2!) -- I went to get a tooth cleaning and heard compliments from the hygienist and dentist. Unbelievable. No cavities. They didn't even mention pop except to suggest I swish with water so it won't stain my exposed root surfaces so much. HA! 20+ years of lectures from dentists about proper brushing technique, all for nothing, the tens of thousands of $ in fillings might all have been significantly reduced with just this.(By the way I *am* brushing mostly by aiming the Sonicare into my gums at an angle and mostly ignoring the surface of my teeth, as instructed.)
  142. I haven't visited my dentist in nearly 5 years (yes, gross I know), and bought this when he recommended it to me to correct the gum abrasion that was happening in my mouth. Apparently I was brushing too hard.<br /><br />The two minute setting is awesome, and using this toothbrush has become a very normal ritual. At first, the feeling of the Sonicare head was very strange at first, but you get used to it after a few days. Sometimes, I will use the one minute Go Care setting if I feel as though I'm extremely rushed. Normally, I use the sensitive setting.<br /><br />I've read some of the negative reviews here, and feel as though if the buttons are getting in the way of your brushing, it means you are gripping the toothbrush handle way too tight. A gentle grasp of the handle with a few fingers along with gliding the toothbrush head along your gum line is all that needs to be done.<br /><br />The battery lasts just about forever, and normally do not need to charge until 3 or 4 weeks later. I took this on a two week vacation without any problem at all.<br /><br />I have not needed to change my toothbrush head yet, but have removed and reattached it during my vacation multiple times without any problems.<br /><br />I think my only complaint would be that I wish you could set a default brush mode. I have to set it to sensitive mode each and every time I brush. I believe it defaults to the Go Care mode.<br /><br />As always, don't forget to floss. This is obviously not the magic answer to the lack of flossing, but it will surely help with those hard brushers like myself.

The seal at the top of the unit allows water to get into the electronics and corrode them. Designed to fail. The unit maybe has $8 worth of parts in it so you'd think that for a $100+ item they would make the seal better especially since it's made for water exposer. Zero excuse Phillips...poorly made product.

  145. I bought this over a year ago. I had another model of the Philips Sonicare toothbrush before that and really liked it so decided to buy this one. The replacement brush heads are reasonably priced and don't need to be changed that often. The battery lasts long so you don't need to leave the stand plugged in if you're conscious of your energy footprint. The device has a battery light to show how much it's charged and the toothbrush is comfortable in your hand while brushing. The brush head does a nice job of cleaning your teeth and getting in close to the gums (as long as the brush isn't overused). My only issue with this toothbrush is the stand. The brush just sort of sits on top of the stand, which makes it pretty easy to knock over. My old brush kind of sat in a cradle, which kept it upright and made it much more difficult to knock over when you are working with a small amount of counter space. Overall, great product and no real complaints other than gravity.

Great item! Should have bought years ago!
  156. I bought this product at my dentist recommendation. I used to brush my teeth very well, but my dentist said the plague keeps building between my teeth as they are no perfectly aligned. This product has made a difference in just few weeks that I have used it thus far. I feel refreshed after using this product. It is not how hard you brush it is actually how good you brush and this product does a pretty good job in cleaning.<br /><br />Note that for initial few days you will notice lot of vibration in your mouth, which would feel very odd, but after a week of usage the vibration will be less bothering. This is the only price that you would have to pay to use this product IMHO.
  157. I am very pleased with my recent purchase of the sonicare electric toothbrush. It is user-friendly and durable. It features a longer brush time and a shorter one so I can have more flexibility in how long I brush my teeth. Excellent product!
  158. This is the second FlexCare toothbrush I have owned. The first lasted about 3 years (not a bad run!). When that toothbrush broke and I had to go back to \\"regular brushing\\", it was a real eye opener as to how great the FlexCare is. My teeth / mouth did not feel clean without it. I really like the timed settings because the force me to take time and work on each section of my teeth. Also I feel that my gums have gotten much healthier with consistent use of the FlexCare. Before trying the FlexCare I had noticed some receding of my gums especially around my front teeth. This was reversed after about 2 months of FlexCare use. Highly recommended.<br /><br />Another note: I previously owned the FlexCare that has the sterilization chamber (not sure what the actual name is). It was a good idea, but got dirty quickly which felt like it was defeating it's very purpose. I actually prefer the regular charging stand. Easy to use and easy to keep clean.

  160. Was given this last Christmas to replace a 3 yr old Sonicare, which had worked well. I am a big fan of Sonicare (teeth really feel clean after using) but this 2nd one has just broken on me after 10 months. The spindle on which the brush sits is now loose and as a result it makes a loud rattling noise when used. I will probably get another one and put it down to bad luck.<br /><br />Do be aware that they are really susceptible to mould on the rear of the base - having owned two of these I have learned that the grippy rubber makes it impossible to remove once it gets on. You really have to be diligent in rinsing and drying the handle after using it.
  161. I didn't understand the point of an electric toothbrush until I got a new dentist, who explained that something like a Sonicare vibrates faster and therefore cleans better than a manual toothbrush. I've had more than my share of cavities, so I picked up a Sonicare Flexcare and have been very impressed!<br /><br />This gadget is very well designed, and as I was learning to use it I kept getting the feeling that Philips thought of everything. (It's almost like an Apple product in that way.) The charging base comes apart for portability while traveling; the brush handle fits to the base without any metal connections, so there's no risk of shock in the bathroom; the brush handle is even waterproof for those who like to brush in the shower. My wife and I share a handle, and the charging base has two pegs to store our brush heads.<br /><br />My only complaint is that this model includes &#34;massage&#34; and &#34;gum care&#34; modes, but I haven't been able to figure out what those do or how to use them. I've read the manual, searched the Philips website, and Googled for other product reviews, and I haven't found anything more explanatory than the names of the buttons. I really don't see the point of including a feature if nobody knows what it does, so if I were buying this again I'd look for a model without these extra modes and try to save a few bucks.<br /><br />But I would definitely buy a Sonicare again.<br /><br />UPDATE: The motor died suddenly (while brushing) after five years of daily use. I guess that's a good ROI, but it seemed so well made that I expected it to last indefinitely. I called Philips and they said it was out of warranty but gave me a 15% off coupon for a new toothbrush from their website. I ended up just coming back to Amazon and buying a new one here.

  165. I have been using the Sonicare Elite 7300 brush for a couple of years now, so it was no surprise to me that the FlexCare line is also a very good brush. All-in-all, using the new FlexCare is not all that much different than the Elite series, it feels about the same despite the advertised 80% less vibration. That being said the vibration does not bother me at all. The two biggest differences I noticed with the FlexCare are the significantly smaller handle size, which could be good if you have smaller hands and the somewhat larger brush head size, which I kind of like, because it seems to clean more areas faster. Of course the new ProResults brush head also means that I can't use the same brush heads that I have already bought for my older brush, but I like the new head design and also the way that it just presses on instead of screwing on like the older heads did.<br /><br />As for all of the brushing modes and cleaning routines offered with this brush, I have not even bothered with them, I like brushing my normal 2 minutes (30 seconds each quadrant) which is what the standard clean mode does, so that is what I use. The charger station is also nice because it can hold two extra brush heads so that up to 3 people can share the same space easily. It also has a \\"travel charger\\" which is just the main charger without the extra brush head spaces and also a cloth-like travel case. The battery life also claims to be longer than any of the previous versions, so taking this on longer trips without even worrying about the charger is more of a possibility.<br /><br />So, in conclusion, I never had any problems with my Elite series brush and I don't expect to have any with the new FlexCare either. It also seems to work just as well if not better and I have had wonderful dentist check-ups for the past several years with no cavities and very little plaque despite the fact that I only brush once a day, so I'm pretty happy with the Sonicare brushes and plan to use them for a long time to come. If you are switching from a regular manual brush up to this it does have a little bit of a weird feeling at first, but other than that first week or so of getting used to it, I really have nothing negative to say about this product.me. If you are switching from a regular manual brush up to this it does have a little bit of a weird feeling at first, but other than that first week or so of getting used to it, I really have nothing negative to say about this product.
  166. This is my 4th or 5th Sonicare toothbrush and my 2nd Sonicare, FlexCare. I have used these toothbrushes for approximately 14 years.   167. This is my second Sonicare product and I remain very impressed. I previously used the Elite for two years and my only annoyance was the design of the Elite brush head and handle. The Elite brush consisted of a screw-on dome that no matter how hard I tried to keep it dry and clean on the inside, it would always get dirty and gross and there was no way to clean it. Similarly on the Elite handle, a deep well that the magnet from the brush head would insert when brush and handle were joined would also collect dirt and was impossible to keep clean. This wasn't a health issue but it was just gross to look at when you disassembled the brush after each use. I found that if I didnt disassemble, a black mold type substance would grow. Even taking it apart after every use would not deter this growth eventually.<br /><br />The new Flexcare brush fixes all of these issues. Gone are the deep crevices and unreachable traps for dirt and moisture. The brush head simply inserts onto a pin on top of the handle. The handle on the Flexcare is smaller than the Elite. As for the reduction in sound and vibration, I can't agree with the packaging because it sounds and feels the same as the Elite to me. There are many more cleaning modes however I just use the clean mode as I did before.<br /><br />Both products clean my teeth nearly as good as the dentist. I always thought an electronic TB was a waste and was finally convinced by my dentist to try one. If you never have used one, you will be amazed at the difference from a manual brush. It takes some getting used to but you will see and feel the difference. See for yourself. After a couple of weeks try a manual brush and your mouth just doesnt feel clean at all. The package contains a charger, travel pouch, travel charger, UV brush sanitizer, 1 regular and one small brush head. My only gripe is that the travel pouch is soft where the Elite had a hard plastic case that held and cradled both the handle and brush. The new cloth pouch offers no protection from crushing or keeping the brush from hitting and possibly scratching the handle.<br /><br />The instructions say you can put the handle in the dishwasher however at this price, I'm not brave enough to try that one. A Great product. If you are shopping for an electric TB, this is the one to get. Your teeth and gums will thank you. I also endure less scraping at the dentist since using this product so that alone is worth the price of this product.m crushing or keeping the brush from hitting and possibly scratching the handle. The instructions say you can put the handle in the dishwasher however at this price, I'm not brave enough to try that one. A Great product. If you are shopping for an electric TB, this is the one to get. Your teeth and gums will thank you. I also endure less scraping at the dentist since using this product so that alone is worth the price of this product.

Even though the book says that there is a small gap, I was sure that it would get gummed up, but it doesn't.<br /><br />Of the three modes, I typically brush in the \\"clean\\" mode. Sometimes when I'm brushing, I accidentally tap the button that changes the modes, and it bumps to \\"sensitive\\". Not a big deal, just thought I'd mention that this happens.<br /><br />I have absolutely no complaints with this purchase, and am overall enthusiastically happy about it, and wish that I'd started using one of these years ago. I'm looking forward to seeing if my dentist observes a difference at my next checkup. I like this so much, that I've gotten my husband to use it.<br /><br />As much as I like this brush - and I got it for a good price - when this bites the dust, I will chance a less expensive model as a replacement.

  170. I have been brushing manually since I was taught how to brush my teeth. I am a smoker and a coffee drinker, yes, and my dentists have always given me a hard time. I see all the work they go through to get my teeth clean. I have been going for checkups every 6 months for last 6 years or so. About 7 years ago, I had 6 veneers put on at a top University with the best staff and equipment, and they recommended that since I smoke, that I should go more frequently to ensure oral health. Over the last 6 years my veneers have taken on some staining, so I have been looking into alternative methods of tooth cleaning.<br /><br />Well, after my hygienist recommended the Sonicare toothbrush system, I thought I would check into it. I Paid 140-ish at a BIG box store for the system with one proresults head. I bought an extra 3 pack of proresults heads so my wife and I could use the system together, for an additional 30.<br /><br />I unpacked it last night, and my first impression was that the charger seemed light and cheap, but the brush itself felt very solid and compact. I glanced over the quickstart guide and I was impatiently waiting for the unit to charge. The unit looks very attractive on the counter, which is a big deal since I do not have much space. My wife and I were tired of seeing our manual toothbrush handles sitting in a pool of slimy leftovers in a decorative toothbrush holder (YUK!), so we threw all that away. This unit looks great!!<br /><br />After some time charging, I gave the unit a go. I was not affected by the sonic pulsations that I have heard other people complain about with other brands. I do have a few sensitive spots, but I was not too bothered by the noise or sensation. It reminds me of that great little tool the dentists have that uses water and sonic waves to BLAST away tartar and calculus off of my teeth.<br /><br />After 2 minutes of working on the distal lingual surfaces, I had a look and WOW! It removed the few months of stain build up which I usually get on those interior surfaces. I should note here that I do not floss everyday like I should, instead I floss every other day or longer when I feel the need. I know I know (I'm lazy).<br /><br />My teeth feel very smooth and are already showing signs of whitening. I may be able to go to a yearly checkup instead of every six months now. I will wait and see what the dentist says. All in all, if you are a smoker, a coffee drinker, or if you have veneers or other dental work you will love this product, it REALLY works!faces.   171. Since there are many other reviews, I'll just mention the highlights. I've been using the low-end Sonicare model for years and was happy with it, except for poor nickel cadmium battery life. It was annoying to have to throw away an expensive toothbrush because the battery would no longer charge. I'm hoping the lithium ion battery in this model will last longer.<br /><br />This model does seem to get my teeth cleaner. It feels like it's doing a better job, and after getting used to it the low-end model feels really wimpy. I like the LED battery indicator because I travel a lot and don't have to guess about when the toothbrush needs to be charged.<br /><br />My only complaint about this toothbrush is that it has some useless features that annoy me. For example, it turns itself off when it thinks you've brushed long enough. I always have to turn it back on. It's not a big deal, just dumb. There doesn't seem to be any way to disable this feature. The instructions indicate you can disable the \\"Quad pacer\\" feature, which I did, but the toothbrush still turns itself off.<br /><br />For a toothbrush in this price range, it's surprising that it doesn't come with at least one extra cleaning head, or a holder for the spare heads.<br /><br />Overall I'm very happy with this toothbrush and plan to use it from now on.
