  182. I'm a dentist and this is an HONEST review from my own personal experience (no sonicare affiliation!)<br /><br />Pros<br />-does a very very thorough job of brushing and cleaning. Once you have sonicared, I guarantee you will never go back to a manual toothbrush. On the days when my brush is charging and I have to brush manually, my teeth just feel so unclean in comparison.<br />-is still gentle during cleaning. This is a big problem with a lot of the other brushes I've encountered (either used or read about in the dental literature). Many other electrical products on the market also do a good job of brushing, but they tend to be TOO aggressive and abrasive, so in the end they end up brushing away your gum and leaving you with gum recession and sensitivity. Sonicare does a thorough but gentle job, leaving your gums intact in the long run. Many of the rotary-styled brushes out there (ie, OralB) are just too abrasive and end up brushing away your gums.<br />-can be shared! If you have a spouse, you can use the same base, just switch the attachment heads. The manufacturer designed this with it in mind, as you can choose from 3-4 different \\"ring\\" colors to put on your attachment head.<br />-easy to clean and stays clean, does not rust or get dirty at the base (this was a problem I had with an older model, so I'm glad to see that they've changed it!)<br />-water resistant/friendly, so you can also use it in the shower during those rushed mornings<br /><br />Cons<br />-mainly, the price. Compared to most other electrical toothbrushes on the market, it's relatively expensive. I would ask your dentist to see if he/she has coupons. Even the attachment heads aren't cheap, and I would suggest getting coupons or using rebates whenever possible (ie, if I had to buy them through retail I would go to Bed Bath& Beyond and use a 20% off coupon from the store)<br />-long charge time, it takes about 18 hours for the base to be recharged once it is out of battery<br /><br />Please remember that no matter what brush you use, you still need to floss!!! :-)you still need to floss!!! :-)

  196. I had an old Sonicare Elite that was no longer holding a charge, and so I asked my dentist to recommend a new one; he recommended this. I'm very happy with it, the brush itself feels very precise and stimulating. It also charges very fast and holds it a long time.<br /><br />My only complaint is the positioning of the button that switches mode (not the main power button - the other one). It's too easy to press it while using the brush, which then switches it from the mode you want to the next mode, and it's not easy to then intentionally put it back where you wanted it without interrupting your brushing. So I find I have to hold the handle at a somewhat unnatural angle to avoid hitting that button. I wish they had designed it so that the mode button was disabled when the unit is on, since I doubt anyone would intentionally switch modes in the middle of a session.<br /><br />Other than that, though, I am very happy with it!<br /><br /> /rob<br /><br />PS - OK, I just thought of one other minor gripe: the shaft of the brush head, just where it enters my mouth, had a little \\"mold mark\\" from where the plastic was formed - a little raised circle about a millimeter across that interrupts the otherwise smooth surface - that causes a little irritation on my lip during use. Sheesh, you'd think they'd make sure these things were completely smooth!

  198. I've tried just about every electronic toothbrush on the market (Sonicare Elite, Braun, Ultreo, and Waterpik), and the new Sonicare Flexcare beats them all.<br /><br />Why?<br /><br />1. Using the regular setting for a two-minute brush leaves my teeth feeling clean, the cleanest of any of the brushes I've tried.<br /><br />2. Multiple power settings include a low power gum massage that's just great. This massage feels as though it stimulates blood flow to the gums, and that just has to be helpful.<br /><br />3. Plus, for new users, there's an Easy Start program built into the brush that allows the brush speed to start slow and increase in power over several days. For users familiar with electronic brushes, however, starting with the regular (full power) setting won't be a problem.<br /><br />4. The charger is solid and heavy enough to avoid the tipping over problems I've experienced with some other brushes. And there's a place to conceal the excess wiring beneath the charger.<br /><br />5. The replacement brushes are reasonably priced. I won't be spending the price of a new setup every year just to get new brush heads. And I appreciate the fact that Phillips is not holding their customers hostage for replacement brush heads.<br /><br />All in all, the new Flexcare is just about perfect. I highly recommend it!
  199. For most people, tooth brushing is a necessary but boring chore. If you brush incorrectly or quickly, you may end up being a permanent fixture in the periodontist's office. Alas, this has happened to me, much to my dismay. To keep your teeth and gums healthy, you might want to try an ounce of prevention: the Sonicare Flex Care 910 Toothbrush. It's rechargeable (a full charge lasts for two weeks), features a timer to tell you when to move on to another section of your mouth, and includes three cleaning modes. In addition, the \\"easy start\\" feature enables you become gradually accustomed to your new cleaning routine. The grip is very comfortable and the brush head is easy to maneuver, even in hard-to-reach areas. I still don't love having to brush my teeth, but since it's a necessary evil, I am thankful to have the Sonicare brush to do most of the work for me. Along with proper flossing (which you should never neglect), it's one of the most helpful ways to make sure that you don't end up with serious gum problems.
  200. Short and simple: This fantastic brush is just like the other Sonicares but without the screw-on design flaw of the other Sonicare models. The other models, which are still being sold everywhere, have this hideous design where the saliva and other brushing liquids seep down into the inner mechanisms of the brush which pool up in a really disgusting way. This new design eliminates all that slew of slime. This brushing action is fantastic just like the older one.
  201. Let me start off by saying I go to the dentist 3 times a year for a cleaning. I have porous teeth and have had a lot of dental work done when I was younger including braces for 6 years. I drink coffee once a day and brush after and I am a light smoker (less then 1/2 pack a day). I'm sure both the coffee and smoking contribute to staining, but I know people who do 10 times more of each and have no staining.<br /><br />I had the Sonic care elite e series for probably more then 10 years. It lasted longer then I ever expected. The battery started failing, so I figured it has more then served it's time and I wanted a new one. I looked at the ones with the sanitizer, but with limited room on the counter, I decided against it. I think the sanitizer is over rated anyway. Unless you're a germ freak. Besides, I clean my brush heads in a light bleach/water mix every so often and I always replace the heads at least every 3 months.<br /><br />My last dentist appt. was in July over 2 months ago. So far I have virtually no signs of staining and I would typically see signs by now and anxiously await my next cleaning which isn't until Nov. I would say I'll give it another month and then it will be a better indication of how well it works, but so far I am pleasantly surprised.<br /><br />The vibration is a bit more intense then my elite series, but it is also a more powerful brush. If you aren't used to this kind of brush, it may take a little getting used to before you don't feel like your head is going to vibrate off your neck :) But seriously, it's doing it's job.<br /><br />There is a special mode you can use (Easy-start) to ramp up to normal use if the vibration is more intense then you like.<br /><br />I GAVE IT 4 STARS BECAUSE (I would of given 4.5 if I could)....... The mode button is in a bad spot. I constantly hit it while brushing changing the mode and I have to switch it back. I usually brush my teeth when I'm in the shower. It's just easier for me and it avoids a potential mess that only a electric toothbrush can produce. So perhaps my hand it more prone to moving around on the handle because it's wet, but I still feel the mode button is in a bad spot and too sensitive as well. Other then that, it's a great tooth brush. Definitely worth the money. For those complaining about the price, you get what you pay for.oduce. So perhaps my hand it more prone to moving around on the handle because it's wet, but I still feel the mode button is in a bad spot and too sensitive as well. Other then that, it's a great tooth brush. Definitely worth the money. For those complaining about the price, you get what you pay for.

  203. This was a replacement for the essence (which after 4.5 years the rubber seal around the power button tore). I do like the bigger handle of the essence a bit better, but I like the brush head mechanism more on this model (the old one got gross under the brush head - really hard to keep clean - unless I just have an abnormal amount of bacteria in my mouth, but that's a topic for a different day). This model, the brush head just pops off and the base is all sealed with no gaps to get mucked up.<br /><br />So all in all, a suitable replacement. I don't use the different modes. It comes with a nylon travel pouch (I prefer a plastic one for ease of clean, but not a deal breaker).<br /><br />And a reminder for those replacing old toothbrushes, do make sure you remove the battery prior to disposal - be earth friendly!
  204. This toothbrush is awesome. It is a little pricey, but absolutely worth it. I am not a fan of electric brushes at all, used many, but by far this brush is the best. It leaves your teeth squeaky clean, and feels good while you use it. Does not damage gums, and it actually ramps up over 2 weeks to full power so that you are not jarred by its power. It's also smaller than any I've used before. Pricey, but worth it.
  205. I have been using these brushes since 2000. My first one lasted 7 years and it was by far the simplest design and the best. Since my original one died I am now on my 3rd one, yup 3 newer Sonicares in the last 5 years. They still work great but there are 2 major flaws with them. First the new blue bristles that tell you when its time to change the brush head, mine always loses its blue in about 6 - 8 weeks, a far cry from the original brush head which lasted for 3 months. The brush is never even used up in 6-8 weeks you can feel the difference when its time to change the head. So ignore the blue. But my biggest complaint is the new design of the head. They used to make the head so the hard plastic case screwed onto the brush holder, which sealed out most of the toothpaste fallout from your mouth, which was a decent design. Now they make them so you just push them onto the base. My problem with this is that you get build up of nasty gook under the base, unless you are like me and remove the brush and rinse and dry it after each use. Even if you do, which I do, there is still a mold issue at the base where the white rubber seal encloses the metal tip. No mater how well I dry it or the fact that I wipe it clean after every use there is still a bit of mold that starts developing along the white rubber seal in the crevice. This bothers me to no end. There should not be mold or any sort of black build up especially if I am rinsing and drying it all the time. I started doing this with my newest one to see if the problem still happened and yes it does. So whereas I love the way my teeth feel when I am done brushing and I won't switch back to a traditional brush I find the new design to be a major flaw and a big profit for Phillips. I am convinced they changed the design of the brush head so they can make more money by selling more heads sooner then necessary, but don't buy into it, that new head should last for at least 3 months even if that blue is gone. The mold is another issue.issue.
  206. The Sonicare has a great 30 second interval so you make sure to spend enough time on all the places. When you use it for the first time you'll wonder why you didn't buy it earlier. If a $100 purchase saves you time, pain, and money at the dentist, then its a great investment!
  207. I liked the product a lot in the beginning. My teeth felt cleaner and looked whiter. Then it stopped vibrating. I emailed Phillips, was under warantee, eventually got a head replacement - BUT this one has such a \\"hair trigger\\" that it's impossible to complete a brushing without having it slip into other speeds or turning off.<br /><br />The solution seems quite simple to me: Move the controls down to the very bottom of the shaft. A user will obviously need to grip it from the middle, right where they now have the controls.<br /><br />I will be shopping for a better product.

  229. i've used Sonicare toothbrushes for years, on advice from my dental hygeinist long ago, and could never go back to regular manual brushing. I've tried it, i just can't get my teeth as clean feeling. I used the Braun initially, i liked it, no complaints. This was many years ago. Then i tried the Sonicare, i loved how it left my teeth feeling.<br /><br />There were a few things i didn't like about the Sonicare. The main one, the worst thing, was the gunk that would build up inside the brush head, no matter how i tried to avoid it. It was high maintenance to keep it clean inside, and despite those efforts, periodically i would throw them away and get a new one because they became so nasty and i couldn't get my fingers into all the places where the gunk built up to clean it out. Needless to say, it was expensive to have to replace the whole toothbrush, maybe once a year or more, even though it still worked ok.<br />i think this was really the only thing i didn't like about that toothbrush--it was the Elite series model. It was still worth it to me to replace them. I get plack inside my teeth, that's why the hygienist recommended the Sonicare in the first place, and it really helps to reduce that, much better than using an old fashioned non electronic toothbrush.<br /><br />So--when i saw this new flex care model from Sonicare, i had to buy one on the spot even though i had come to the store (Bed Bath and Beyond)(coupons in hand) to just buy new brushes for my old Sonicare. I love how it's smaller and easily fits in the hand, it's light, and it's very powerful. It looks less obtrusive than the Elite. But best of all, it's designed in a way so that there is no way for the brush to get any built up nasty gunk inside it. It's a simple small brush design that fits over the end of the handle, no mechanical parts, no dark damp compartment where things can grow. And the sterilizer is nice too.<br /><br />It's clear enough that the Sonicare company wanted to make an advance in the quality of this product with this new design. One of the known downfalls of this kind of tooth brush has been accumulation of bacteria and the dreaded gunk. I had searched the web for some kind of solution to this and found that it was a common problem. It's hard for me to imagine now how this design could be improved on.<br /><br />as another review said, this tooth brush should be used with a very light touch, lightly holding the brush up against the teeth, the brush moves very fast and pressing down very hard will just interfere with what it does so well. I find this difficult, i tend to want to press down more than is necessary. I think it's probably not good for the motor. But habitually i've tended to press down more than what would be best. Again, it needs to be just lightly held against the surface of the tooth. My hygienist told me this.is product with this new design.   234. Let's face it, from the times our mothers insisted that we brush thoroughly, we have failed miserably. Electric toothbrushes have been on the market for many years, but most people don't use them. Now a new generation of sonic toothbrush has hit the shelves. The real question are these toothbrushes going to replace the buck and a quarter manual brush on your sink?<br /><br />The answer is surprising, they should. The Phillips Sonicare brush has three speeds, one for massaging gums, one for sensitive teeth and gums and one for cleaning. The instrument has a built in thirty second timer set so each quadrant gets a full thirty second treatment. It is a lot more convenient the egg timer my mother gave me in the sixties. On top of that it is hard to ignore. If you move to a new quadrant before the momentary pause, you tend to feel a bit guilty.<br /><br />But the real test of this toothbrush is how your mouth will feel after using it. It is much like the sensation after a visit to the dental hygienist. When your dentist recommends this brush, follow the advice. You won't be sorry.
  235. I think those who are looking for a lighter weight and smaller diameter handle will be pleased with this version. It cleans as well as the regular Sonicare, although it took me a few sessions to get used to less force and less time in brushing (I have the E9800)while using the initial program setting. This is also a very good brush for those w/ gum erosion or sensitive teeth. Since you can get the one w/ the santizer for only $10 more, I'd suggest that combo. I also have the regular Sonicare santizer which works well, but it also costs around $50, so the combo listed here is a better deal. I really think Philips has overtaken the electric toothbrush market for a few good reasons-quality brushes, desired features, durability, easy to find replacement heads, and THEY ARE the one brand recommended by the 2 different dentists' offices I have gone to in the past year.
  236. I want to stress that this brush works superbly. My 3 stars are for the value/bang for your buck aspect of this product.<br /><br />I have used three other electric brushes besides this one. One was a very early model Sonicare, the other two were Braun Oral-B models. ALL of them worked great. The three other brushes I've used have all had excellent durability. And I never had a single cavity with any of them.<br /><br />There are really just two major differences between these two brands. Brauns tend to have smaller heads and they have a kind of rotating pulsing motion. Sonicare models have more of a vibration motion and, in my experience, tend to tickle a bit more. Your mileage may vary. In my experience, Braun brush heads also tend to be a little cheaper.<br /><br />All the electric toothbrush makers make claims about being the \\"best.\\" However, as one major dental site commented, \\"There are currently no studies that we are aware of that compare objectively electric toothbrushes. The choice is really a personal one.\\" If you look at multiple objective dental sources you'll find the same kind of advice - choose according to your own preference, not the PR spin of the companies making the brushes.<br /><br />This specific model has 3 cleaning modes, 2 \\"routine\\" modes, 2 minute timer, a quad pacer (30 seconds per quarter of your mouth), and a few other lesser features. The thing is, all of these exist on many other brushes, many of them about $50 (or more) cheaper than this one. If you're looking for just a good electric brush then I can't recommend this model. For about $50 less you can get, for example, the Braun 8850 . . . or the Sonicare e5500, to name just two. They both have most of the exact same features as this model.<br /><br />For the exact same money you can get the Oral-B Triumph 9900 with Smart Guide. That model tells you, graphically, when you're brushing too hard (which causes major permanent gum damage) and when you need to replace the brush head. Those are the kind of extras I'd be willing to pay for. All the extra modes and timers I find to be a bit useless.<br /><br />Pros: This Sonicare model works and works well<br />Cons: It's over priced for the features. There are better choices on the market.brush head. Those are the kind of extras I'd be willing to pay for. All the extra modes and timers I find to be a bit useless.<br /><br />Pros: This Sonicare model works and works well<br />Cons: It's over priced for the features. There are better choices on the market.
  237. My wife and I have been using the Philips Sonicare Rechargeable Toothbrushes for several months. My wife has been using the model sans UV Sanitizer and has been pretty happy with it. The rechargeable base is interchangeable with the higher end model (which includes the Sanitizer), allowing my wife and I to share a unit (and give us more bathroom counter space). This particular model offers the same three modes of brushing that the higher model does. Initial setup involves plugging the base unit into an AC outlet and letting the brush charge.<br /><br />The toothbrush easily fits into its charging unit, and does a thorough job in cleaning our teeth and gums, especially in harder to reach places. The three modes are easy on sensitive teeth, and apply enough pressure to clean the gums without causing them to erode. The unit itself is easy to clean and maintain, and appears to be well thought out in terms of both holding the toothbrush, as well as placement of the mode buttons.<br /><br />It is important to note that brush refills are on the expensive side, but, from our experience, the brushes themselves appear to last longer than conventional toothbrushes do. We very much like our Philips Sonicare toothbrushes and would recommend them to others wholeheartedly.

I use the setting that allows 30 seconds for each quadrant of teeth before transmitting a little beep.   253. You've decided to invest in a good toothbrush - but do you really want to spend this kind of cash on a toothbrush every year? After 12 months of use, my unit's battery has become so weak that every single time I use the brush the 'recharge me' light blinks - even if I'm just using it for 20 seconds. So the charger is always plugged in on the counter, and my husband and I alternate charging the darn things every day and night just to get our 2 minutes of brushing in. I like the way it cleans my teeth, although the horrible smell when you change the brush heads - and the evil slime that builds up in there - is disquieting. I'd try Oral B next time.
  254. We've had the Flexcare toothbrush for about 2 months now. A negative is there are several choices for brushing mode and there is the chance you will accidentally change to another mode without knowing it by hitting the wrong button.

  261. I suspect most of the people reviewing this product wrote the review before they had to change the brush. I bought a 3-pack of replacement heads with the main unit, after a couple of months it was time to change the head. The instructions say pull the old one off, push the new one on. Seems simple enough, right?<br /><br />Not so much. The new head didn't feel firmly connected and fell off when brushing. I tried twisting, pushing hard, you name it. Eventually I found some online forums that said replacement heads were sometimes defective so I tried another. It was a little tighter but still fell off during the first brushing. I tried the third, same thing.<br /><br />I'm now stuck with a base unit without a brush head. I refuse to buy yet another replacement pack so I'm going to try Oral B instead. Don't waste your money on this product, you'll get to use it until you need to replace the brush and then it's useless.

He said that it was a good product (and I agree) but be careful of the pressure. I purchased this product on January 21, 2010 and it is still going strong! Not having dental insurance, I try to do everything I can at home to take care of my teeth and cut down on potential dental costs. When I started using this toothbrush, I had some tartar build up on my back molars. Yes, tartar,not plaque. The hardened, calcified stuff. Within six months of using the Sonicare FlexCare toothbrush (used in combination with Colgate Tartar Control toothpaste - don't know if that made any difference), without any visits to the dentist, that tartar was gone and I was amazed! This is the first sonic toothbrush I've ever used so I can't compare it to any others, but I have been nothing but pleased with the way it works. A truly great product!

  288. This is the third Sonicare toothbrush I have purchased either for myself or other family members. The first was purchased a bit more than two years ago and is still going strong-after being used at least twice each day. Another lasted a little over a year for my wife before it started having problems charging and turning off- had to knock off two stars for that. To be fair, her toothbrush developed a slight tear in the brush stub seal, so that may have allowed moisture to enter the handle body. Still, the seal failure should not have occurred from daily use. I am careful to keep the handle clean and dry, so perhaps that helps even if the sealing is imperfect. I also let the battery run down until the brush ceases operating- then I fully recharge it (takes about a full day) before putting away the charger. I easily get two weeks of daily use (minimum twice a day, three on weekends) before it requires another recharge, and that is with using it in the full clean mode. By the way, I found a place on E bay where you can get a replacement battery if/when you need one. Just perform a search for \\"Sonicare FlexCare\\" and you should be able to find it.<br /><br />Why did I state that 'the results are worth it'? I had changed dental insurance companies and therefore dentists. Because of that, professional teeth cleaning was put off for a year and a half. My new dentist remarked how clean my teeth were (this was after using the Sonicare toothbrush for that entire time period) and noted how improved my scores were over the previous cleaning record (I do keep track). My previous dentist always wanted to perform cleaning three times a year due to plaque buildup. Could simply be due to the differences in the professional staffing, but I tend to doubt it.
  289. About ten years ago, I bought a twofer, Sonicare Elite, at Costco and still have one of them, as a back-up, if I ever have to get my new Sonicare FlexCare repaired. This new R910 Sonicare Flexcare is a treat to use: It is now, very lightweight and more hygienic because of the improved design of the head, eliminating the old, screw-down collar that collected moisture and got real grungy. The new shaft has a lightweight, rubber grip. And, you don't have to hold it in your palm, like a baseball bat, but between your fingertips, more like a flute. (I also discovered that there is a small, plastic sheet from the factory, over the control face, which can be removed, just like the plastic sheet over the microwave panel when it's just out of the box.) I especially like the variable brushing settings, from \\"regular\\" to \\"sensitive\\" to \\"massage\\". Personally, I like to brush for 2-4 minutes and then do a massage on the gums for another 2 minutes. The charging base is smaller and lighter, along with a space, (when you remove the bottom cover), to wrap the cord, when traveling.<br /><br />P.S. I only accidentally hit the power button, once. If you've, previously, had an Elite, it may take you a few days to get used to the new narrow, lightweight design.

  297. I love this toothbrush!<br /><br />I have no patience for trying to time my toothbrushing sessions, but with this brush I don't have to worry about it. It is set to time each quadrant of your teeth.<br /><br />The Max Care setting is for the dentist recommended amount of time to brush your teeth. I usually use that one, but for those times when I am on the go, there is also Go Care, which is a faster setting.<br /><br />You can even turn off the brush during the sessions so that you can spit when you need to and it will pick up where you left off! I didn't know it did this for about the first couple of weeks I had it! I thought it had to stay on the whole time or it would start the timer over, lol!!<br /><br />Each session takes you through clean, sensitive and massage settings. If you don't want to brush your teeth on a timer, you can also choose one of those settings individually.<br /><br />If you keep it plugged in all the time, the charge can last you a while. I went on a cruise recently for four days and didn't bring the charger (although it's small enough to not be a big deal to bring along!), but the brush lasted me the whole weekend, without plugging it in!<br /><br />I also love that it doesn't take up much room on my sink, the stand/charger is small, and the design of both the stand and the brush is very sleek. It also comes with a plastic cover to put over your brush when it's not in use. And a cute travel case to take your brush with you (does not carry the carger, only the brush), I can even fit a travel-size Sensodyne Pronamel toothpaste in the case too!<br /><br />I definitely recommend this brush!

  306. This is the third electric toothbrush I have tried in the last year and this one stands heads and shoulders over the other two. The first I tried was the [[ASIN:B000V4O1UA Ultreo Ultrasound Toothbrush]] which always felt awkward and replacement heads were expensive and not in my local stores. On the other hand, the Phillips Sonicare just seemed to fit the first time. Perhaps I am more adjusted to the feel of electric toothbrushes, but this one did not feel like I was brushing with a tennis racket. Also, replacement brushes are readily available and reasonably priced.<br /><br />The second brush I tried was the cheaper [[ASIN:B00132FUNG Waterpik Sensonic Professional Toothbrush]], which I was very happy with it. But a few friends kept raving about their Sonicares so I figured I better try one. The Sonicare probably costs twice what the Waterpik costs but it's worth it. It was kind of like driving a BMW when you are used to driving a PT Cruiser. The Waterpik was good and got the job done, but this brush just had a feel of quality.<br /><br />This brush also has some great features, like the quick brushing, and although I didn't try it, there was a setting to ease new users into the world of electric toothbrushes. I have to say I'm am not that into the whistles and bells, I just wanted my teeth brushed, and I feel this brush was noticibly better than the other two. It's a well constructed, effective brush and my first recomendation to anyone looking for a brush. If you want a cheaper brush, I was happy with the Waterpik, but I would lean toward spending the extra.

It gets into more spaces, loosens debris better and maintains gums better than a rotating brush.   313. I've been using an older Sonicare model, the \\"Essence 5300\\" on which the switch was beginning to go out. I decided to upgrade to a Flexcare model and am very glad I did. The Flexcare has been a great improvement all around.<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />-New Lighter, Slimmer Handle<br />This is probably the first thing you'll notice if you're coming from an older Sonicare handle, and it is a very welcome improvement. The FlexCare handle is small and feels much better in the hand than my old bulky 5300 handle. The unit is actually longer than my old brush, but that's not a big deal at all.<br /><br />-New ProResults Brush Head system<br />The new heads are great. Sonicare moved the tuning fork from the head to the handle, which means smaller brush heads than on the old models. A 3 pack of the new heads is the same price as a 2 pack of the old heads, making them actually a better deal for a superior product.<br /><br />-No More Crud in the Handle!<br />The biggest problem with my old brush was that old toothpaste/drool/water tended to collected in the space where the handle connects to the brush head. It would get all moldy and gross if you didn't clean it out regularly. Thankfully, this problem is completely gone with the Flexcare handles.<br /><br />-Lithium Ion Batteries<br />I've waited a long time for Sonicare to upgrade from inferior NiCd batteries, and they finally have. With Lithium Ion, you don't have to worry about battery capacity decreasing over time, or a memory effect. The new batteries charge faster, too.<br /><br />-Quadpacer<br />This is basically a beep that goes off every 30 seconds while brushing, reminding you to switch to a new area of your mouth. It has appeared in previous models (not my 5300 though), and is nice if you'll use it, but I tend to go at my own pace as I focus more on problem areas in my mouth and less on others.<br /><br />-5 Total Brushing Modes/Routines<br />There are 3 selectable \\"modes\\": clean mode: (2 minutes broken into 30 second segments), sensitive (a \\"gentler\\" clean mode) and massage (the brush pulsates for gum stimulation). Go Care Routine shortines the standard 2 minute clean mode to 1 minute, while Max Care is a longer, 3 minute cycle that includes both clean and massage mode. I set the brush on clean mode and tend not to use the other options, but some may find them useful.<br /><br />-More Environmentally Friendly<br />Although buying a new product of any sort will always have a negative environmental footprint, these new brushes are better than the old models due to their Li-Ion batteries, reduced bulk, and lower waste in the smaller replacement brush heads.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />-Price<br />Let's be clear on this: a Sonicare toothbrush is a luxury product. You're paying a lot more up front, and you get to keep paying more every time you buy replacement heads. Surprisingly, heads for Flexcare units are actually a cheaper than the older models; you get 3 Flexcare heads for the same price as 2 of the old heads. The per head price is still several times what it would cost to buy a new manual brush; but for me the superior cleaning is worth it.<br /><br />Noise<br />-Flexcare models are louder than older models. I'm not sure why this is, and supposedly vibration has been reduced in exchange, but the noise can be too much for some. The UV sanitizer also makes a quiet electric \\"hum\\" when plugged in with the door closed, even if the UV bulb isn't run.<br /><br />-Buttons can be depressed while brushing<br />A couple of people have complained about accidentally hitting 1 of the 2 buttons on the handle while brushing. It hasn't happened to me, but for completeness I'll include this as a possible con.<br /><br />Overall:<br /><br />This brush is a vast improvement over my previous brush, and has fixed most of the problems I had without introducing any significant new ones. The fact that replacement brush heads are actually cheaper than on my old brush is a big plus. I highly recommend the Flexcare brushes as a great upgrade to any toothbrush, electric or manual, that you're currently using.
  314. I was used to the E series. Those heads had to go every 2 months for me.They wouldn't even last the 3 months as claimed. This brush head is STILL WORKING FINE. I don't get it, but I still have the extra brush heads that came with the unit. As I said before it is light, easy to clean and very maneuverable. I can't imagine any improvement!

This is the best toothbrush I have ever used and bought one for my husband after enjoying mine so thoroughly.<br />After just 6 months of using this toothbrush instead of a manual, my reqular dental cleaning showed just a minor fraction (10-15%?) of the tartar and buildup that I previously had at my 6 monthly cleaning.<br /><br />The price on Amazon was amazing and shipment was lightning fast.<br /><br />The base design is so clever! The tiny travel charger slips underneath and inside a slightly larger base (although still a small footprint), creating a more stable support for everyday countertop use.<br /><br />The only potentially non-positive comment I have on the toothbrush is that there are too many different functions, if you are the kind of person that chooses one and sticks to it. It certainly doesn't detract from the amazing way the brush works and, at Amazon's low low price, I didn't even bother to look for a toothbrush with fewer functions. With that said, I do appreciate additional programs such as 'GoCare' - the quick touch-up brushing.<br /><br />You will never regret buying this toothbrush. Our whole family has converted!!

  329. I used the first generation Sonicare Advance for many years, because I thought it was a great improvement over a manual toothbrush. The FlexCare is the \\"advanced\\" Advance - there is just no comparison. Most importantly, my teeth felt cleaner with the FlexCare than with the Advance. But there are many other advantages of the Flexcare as well.<br /><br />The FlexCare is much easier to hold because of its rounded shape, slimness and lighter weight. That makes a significant difference when you're holding and moving something around in your mouth for 2 minutes.<br /><br />The only thing that's the same between the two models is the 30 second beeps which signal you to change the area being brushed. But now, instead of just one two-minute brushing mode, the FlexCare has several options which are easily selected by a push of a button. You can do a 1 minute \\"quick\\" brush when you're in a rush - and the brush will beep every 15 seconds instead of 30. Or you can do a 3 minute \\"maximum\\" brush which includes a 30 second brush plus a 15 second gum massage for each area. The gum massage is a nice feature - I liked the feeling of just a gentle massage. You can even opt for just the gum massage without any brushing. And for people with sensitive teeth, there's a sensitive mode (although I haven't tried it.)<br /><br />Other seemingly minor features were actually very user-friendly details that really won me over. First was the brush head attachment, which unlike the Advance, is a single piece which is designed so that excess water that drips down the side of the brush can can be wiped off. Any of you Advance users out there know that excess water can easily collect between the two pieces of the Advance brush head and create yellowish-brownish gunk between the two pieces, unless you always take the two pieces apart and wipe them regularly.<br /><br />Second was the charger base. It includes a cord wrap, which you can use to hide the excess cord within the charger so that you don't have a long cord snaking around your sink. Also, when the cord wrap is removed, the charger converts to a smaller travel size. And a travel case is included.<br /><br />In trying to improve the Advance, Sonicare was thinking of not just the performance of the brush, but how to make it easier and more flexible for the user. And they certainly succeeded. I recommend the FlexCare for top gums and teeth.rd snaking around your sink. Also, when the cord wrap is removed, the charger converts to a smaller travel size. And a travel case is included. In trying to improve the Advance, Sonicare was thinking of not just the performance of the brush, but how to make it easier and more flexible for the user. And they certainly succeeded. I recommend the FlexCare for top gums and teeth.

As a result, the toothbrush is quite manueverable and easy to use, an important feature if you use it for the recommended 2 minutes.<br /><br />The toothbrush is very easy to use, in that you basically push a button to descide which of the clearning modes you want to use (basically there is a 2-minute clearning cycle, with the option of a one-minute quick clean or a3 minute cycle that works in a minute of gum massage. There is also a light that indicates how well charged the battery is.<br /><br />One nice feature of the toothbrush is that it briefly stops (i.e., for a second) as you brush to remind you to move the brush to another quadrant of your mouth, helping assure that your brushing is complete. After two minutes, the unit shuts off.<br /><br />This is an excellent product that does a great job and is easy to use. It really helps meet your brushing needs in that you can set it for different lengths of time (also there is a setting for sensitive teeth). The feature that tells you to move the brush to another part of your mouth is very helpful and really makes it easy to give your teeth a thorough brushing.<br /><br />Very highly recommended!

  335. I used to suffer from gingivitis between teeth cleanings and sometimes it could get pretty bad. After switching to this toothbrush, it completely disappeared. One of the first questions the hygienist asked me was 'Do you use a Sonicare?' I think that says a lot.<br /><br />So I have to consider this value for money. It's expensive, and the new brush heads are expensive, but still, it's gotta be cheaper than the dental treatment I imagine myself needing if I don't use this. The hygienist also said something about (and I paraphrase), 'biofilm', that gets on your teeth and causes decay. A normal toothbrush can't get this off, but a Sonicare just breezes through it.<br /><br />Anyhow, it's reliable, the charge lasts a long time, the gum massage function seems a bit kooky, but feels nice, and it has a timer to ensure that I brush properly.   336. I have used an Oral-B sonic toothbrush for several years. I have been quite happy with the results I get from it. I wondered whether there is something better so I selected this toothbrush. Quite simply, I am amazed.<br /><br />The first thing I noticed is that this toothbrush is lighter. Second, the head has a thinner stem than my current toothbrush, making it easier to maneuver around my mouth. Third, the toothbrush seems to hold a charge longer than my current toothbrush, and it seems to hold one longer than when my current toothbrush was new. Fourth, this thing is loaded with settings.<br /><br />This toothbrush features three two-minute cleaning modes that are selectable from the handle. The most vigorous mode is \\"Clean,\\" followed by \\"Sensitive,\\" and then \\"Massage.\\" As you are going through the routine, a beep sounds every thirty seconds to let you know to move to another quadrant in your mouth. The toothbrush shuts off automatically at the end of these modes.<br /><br />Two other modes serve other purposes. GoCare is a one minute routine for quick cleanings between regular brushing. MaxCare features a two minute \\"Clean\\" period followed by a one minute \\"Massage\\" period. I like this brushing mode the best.<br /><br />Some people may find the various modes to be overkill. I personally like the MaxCare feature and the ability to choose between \\"Clean\\" and \\"Sensitive.\\" Those choices may not seem like a big deal until you have oral surgery. I do not use all the modes, but who knows, some day I might.<br /><br />The Good: Easy to maneuver around your mouth with the slender head. The charge lasts a long time. This model has lots of features.<br /><br />The Bad: Whoa! This model is expensive. Most sonic toothbrushes are expensive when compared to your typical manual toothbrush, but this one seems expensive for what you get. I confess that I really like this model, but I struggle with the price. Also, all that money and only one brush? Wait until you see how much replacement brushes cost!<br /><br />There are a lot of ways to brush your teeth. Sonic toothbrushes are nice because they help massage your gums in addition to cleaning your teeth. The built-in timer is nice too. However, you have to justify spending quite a lot on this model, and then spending even more on replacement heads. I love this model and will use it until it breaks, but I doubt I will purchase anything as fancy (read expensive) to replace it.<br /><br />The four stars are for the features. It would have been five stars but for the price.<br /><br />Good luck!here are a lot of ways to brush your teeth. However, you have to justify spending quite a lot on this model, and then spending even more on replacement heads. I love this model and will use it until it breaks, but I doubt I will purchase anything as fancy (read expensive) to replace it. The four stars are for the features.   337. Recently I had been seeing (actually feeling with my tongue) plaque deposits on my teeth and decided to try out a power-brush. It is easier to hold and maneuver and the increased brushing power is noticeable.<br /><br />What I like about this product.... you are 'forced' to brush for two minutes. Now granted this model does give you a 'quickie' option, but unless you are really in a hurry why would you use it, when the 2-minute brushing is the recommended way to go?<br /><br />I like the smaller charging unit.<br /><br />I also really like the new way the brush heads attach. The older models screwed onto the base unit and invariable you needed to often unscrew the brush and clean where the two attached. Water/dirt ALWAYS accumulated. This new model just pops right onto the base....no place for water/dirt/toothpaste to gather.<br /><br />What I don't like about this model, and it is really a minor annoyance, is that you can easily while brushing hit the buttons and cause the brush to shut off.<br /><br />All in all a great improvement to a great product.   340. I've owned this for 1-year now, and I am perfectly happy with the purchase.<br /><br />__________________________________________<br />THE GOOD:<br />After one year of using it about twice a day, every day, it still works just as well as the first time. The battery is great; I've gone as long as a week without having to charge and even after a year can still go several days without charging (though there is certainly a difference in vibration intensity between a full charge and low charge).<br /><br />Included travel case is also a very handy, useful bonus. Didn't think I'd use it much but I have quite a few times, and it's perfect for when I do.<br /><br />Comfortable to hold as well, and easy to keep clean. Still looks like new and all I ever do is rinse it off for a few seconds after each use.<br /><br />Teeth and gums also feel great after brushing, much better than a toothbrush. I did use a normal toothbrush on a handful of occasions over the past year and I definitely feel that even when I brush for longer, I never feel I'm getting 'quite as clean' of a result compared to the electric. Or maybe I just lost my toothbrush technique/comfort, certainly possible.<br /><br />There is of course no substantiated proof that it is better to brush with an electric. That said though, my dentist has complimented me on particularly good teeth/gum cleaning and health over the past year, but that's more likely due to the convenience and effectiveness of this brush making it easier for me to stick to the habit. Either way, it's definitely a good thing in favor of the brush.<br /><br />Lastly, brush heads seem to last longer/perform better than past electric brushes I've used. I've been perfectly content going through about one head every quarter, which at ~$20-30/year isn't bad!<br /><br />__________________________________________<br />THE BAD:<br />I will agree with another reviewer, in that for the price you're really not getting much improvement over a typical electric brush you could likely find for a good $30-$50 cheaper. I used a ~$40 Brawn electric brush for 2 years before this, and there wasn't too much of a difference in upgrading to this (despite the price being much higher). Although, it does appear they've lowered the price quite a bit over the past year, which I definitely feel is appropriate.<br /><br />Additionally, I found the other modes for brushing rather useless. I played with it for a while, but at the end of the day turning tooth brushing into a project wasn't for me. I look more for the quick, convenient, result.<br /><br />__________________________________________<br />IN SHORT:<br />Pros:<br />- Durable, reliable, long-lasting.<br />- Good, long-lasting battery, and easy to charge.<br />- Comfortable to hold and use, easy to clean.<br />- Convenient travel case included.<br />- Excellent in cleaning teeth/gums.<br />- Replacement brush heads of good quality and value.<br />- Helps keep teeth-brushing `fun' and as less of a chore, making it easier to develop and keep good dental hygiene habits.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Price is much higher than other mostly equivalent models (but who knows, maybe they would've crapped out by now?).<br />- Extra settings/modes relatively useless (subjective, of course).<br /><br />Look forward to getting another 1-2 years out of this before considering an upgrade, and will definitely aim for Sonicare again. Happy customer.<br /><br />***EDIT 10/11/2012<br /><br />This, bumps the product up to a 5-star from my original 4-star.<br /><br />I'm about a month away from the 2-year mark, and I started to experience problems with the brush. The vibration was losing strength, and causing a loud grinding noise when any pressure was applied. It still worked as normal for a while, but progressively got worse to the point where the brush was hardly vibrating at all. This was incredibly discouraging as it wasn't all that old of a toothbrush (and expensive!), but I caved and was willing to repurchase a new one as I was very happy with it otherwise.<br /><br />Low and behold though, before purchasing I noticed a 2-year warranty. I called up customer support and in 5 minutes I had a brand new replacement brush (a free head included!) on the way, at absolutely no cost to me, one month before the warranty ended.<br /><br />Yeah, seriously. A brand new and completely free brush and brush head. No shipping costs, no service costs, no charges at all. And very painless over the phone; great customer care.<br /><br />So yes, while I did have to deal with a faulty product, the astounding customer support and warranty replacement program more than makes up for it. 5-stars.chase a new one as I was very happy with it otherwise.<br /><br />Low and behold though, before purchasing I noticed a 2-year warranty. I called up customer support and in 5 minutes I had a brand new replacement brush (a free head included!) on the way, at absolutely no cost to me, one month before the warranty ended.<br /><br />Yeah, seriously. A brand new and completely free brush and brush head. No shipping costs, no service costs, no charges at all. And very painless over the phone; great customer care.<br /><br />So yes, while I did have to deal with a faulty product, the astounding customer support and warranty replacement program more than makes up for it. 5-stars.

It is easy to accidentally push one of the two control buttons, which can result in stopping the device in the middle of cleaning, or spraying the toothpaste all over.   348. This toothbrush really does a great job of cleaning even with a soft brush, so long as you apply a bit of pressure. The one drawback is the built-in timer that, so far as i can tell, cannot be turned off. The company has decided how long you should brush and to carry out their intentions, the timing mechanism beeps once a minute. It's not the sound that is so objectionable but rather the fact that the beep slightly zaps the brush off your tooth surface, breaking your rhythm and causing the brush to miss the spot it was about to brush. This happens twice per cycle and after three minutes the brush automatically turns off.<br /><br />I don't appreciate that my toothbrush has that much of a mind of its own. I would much prefer making my own brushing decisions!
  349. This Sonicare electric toothbrush is, simply put, an excellent product. I've been using a Braun (which I believe is the same as Oral B) electric toothbrush for years, and it does not compare with this newest generation of dental hygiene products.<br /><br />This model comes preset with a step-up program that gradually increases the speed of the brush head over 14 uses until it reaches maximum effectiveness, a feature designed especially to those new to electric toothbrushes. Although I've used an electric toothbrush for years, I decided to try out the pre-programmed sessions to see how it worked. On the first day, the toothbrush sounded like a bee in my mouth; it was gentle, with enough high-speed vibration to clean my teeth better than my old, full-speed Braun. Over the fourteen uses -- I did it in a week, but those new to electric toothbrushes might want to use it only once a day at first -- the brush lost its whine and gradually moved to its final, more authoritative vibration that cleans exceptionally well. Even at maximum power, this toothbrush does not vibrate through my entire skull the way my Braun does.<br /><br />The coolest part of the Sonicare is the option of selecting different modes. The sensitive teeth setting is more like a mosquito than a bee; although I have sensitive teeth, I find that the regular cleaning doesn't bother me and is more thorough. You may select \\"Go Care\\" (a one-minute touch up between regular brushings), \\"Massage\\" for the gums, and MaxCare for a 30 second tooth brushing following by a fifteen second gum massage for each quadrant (total time = 3 minutes.) To remind you to switch \\"quadrants\\" of your mouth, the pitch changes slightly. After the routine time is up, the toothbrush stops.<br /><br />First time electric toothbrush users should note the instructions about angling the brush head and moving gently side to side. You do not move the brush much yourself as you would with a traditional tooth brush; otherwise, you'll irritate or even rip your gums. My dentist has always advocated using an electric toothbrush once a day, not twice, with a traditional brush doing the work for the second brushing, although I find that the Sonicare, unlike my old Braun, is gentle enough to use twice. Still, users might not want to throw out their toothbrushes.<br /><br />The Sonicare comes with a stand charger, one standard brush head, user identification bands, a soft carrying case, and a plastic cap to protect the brush head while traveling. Those who have smaller mouths will want to buy the optional [[ASIN:B000FEF1VO Philips Sonicare Elite (E-Series) Replacement Brush Head, Compact (2-Pack)]] since it's not easy maneuvering the head behind, say, the front teeth. If you are concerned about sanitizing the heads, you might prefer to buy the version with the sanitizer ([[ASIN:B0012AOO1I Philips Sonicare Flexcare Professional with UV Sanitizer]]), although you can always buy a sanitizer separately later ([[ASIN:B000V5Z4J6 Philips Sonicare UV Sanitizer]].)<br /><br />I have only two complaints about this product: you cannot attach it to the wall to keep counter space free, and the automatic stop feature is annoying if I'm not quite done brushing. The inability to mount it on the wall is especially frustrating since the handle is incredibly easy to knock off the charger. Some people might not like the fact that it tickles like the Dickens when you hit the roof of your mouth while on the brushing speeds.<br /><br />I highly recommend this toothbrush. Electric toothbrushes promote oral health through both cleaner teeth and gum stimulation, and the Sonicare is an exceptional entry into the market.our gums. My dentist has always advocated using an electric toothbrush once a day, not twice, with a traditional brush doing the work for the second brushing, although I find that the Sonicare, unlike my old Braun, is gentle enough to use twice. Still, users might not want to throw out their toothbrushes. The Sonicare comes with a stand charger, one standard brush head, user identification bands, a soft carrying case, and a plastic cap to protect the brush head while traveling. Those who have smaller mouths will want to buy the optional [[ASIN:B000FEF1VO Philips Sonicare Elite (E-Series) Replacement Brush Head, Compact (2-Pack)]] since it's not easy maneuvering the head behind, say, the front teeth. If you are concerned about sanitizing the heads, you might prefer to buy the version with the sanitizer ([[ASIN:B0012AOO1I Philips Sonicare Flexcare Professional with UV Sanitizer]]), although you can always buy a sanitizer separately later ([[ASIN:B000V5Z4J6 Philips Sonicare UV Sanitizer]].) I have only two complaints about this product: you cannot attach it to the wall to keep counter space free, and the automatic stop feature is annoying if I'm not quite done brushing. The inability to mount it on the wall is especially frustrating since the handle is incredibly easy to knock off the charger. Some people might not like the fact that it tickles like the Dickens when you hit the roof of your mouth while on the brushing speeds. I highly recommend this toothbrush. Electric toothbrushes promote oral health through both cleaner teeth and gum stimulation, and the Sonicare is an exceptional entry into the market.
  350. I love the way my teeth feel after using this toothbrush. There is simply no comparison between the Sonicare and a cheap electric toothbrush (let alone a \\"regular\\" hand held). The vibration takes a couple of uses to get accustomed to, and I'm not sure it would feel great if you have overly sensitive teeth. There are different settings which are essentially different time settings (for a quick clean or a longer clean). Not sure how critical the feature is, but it works.<br /><br />There is just one annoying feature of the toothbrush. The controls for the different speeds and timing are all on side of the handle, and I am constantly hitting them accidentally while I'm brushing, either turning it off, or changing the mode mid-session. Not the end of the world, and I'm not sure what other design would allow you the options this brush provides. That is the only reason that I give this brush 4 and not 5 stars.
  351. I used to think that any power toothbrush would be as good as the next. Then I used the Sonicare and it has blown away all expectations and completely transformed my impression about electric toothbrushes.<br /><br />Using this toothbrush has given me an unbelievably long lasting clean taste. It probably gets everything you're going after when you brush.<br /><br />It has a quick brush setting and a longer mode for a thorough scrubbing with a timer to remind you to switch to different areas of the mouth. That's an invaluable feature!<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. I liked the step-up power cycle feature which increases the intensity of the vibrations gradually over the first 14 brush cycles and hits peak only once you've had the chance to use it for a week to two (depending upon how many times you brush daily).<br />2. The brush is ergonomically designed to be easy to a) Hold b) Brush c) clean d) carry in travel pouch<br />3. Gum Massage feature: Lower frequency vibrations help.<br />4. You can wrap the excess length of the power cord in the base and hide it from view.<br />5. I have not replaced the brush on its base for about 3 weeks now and it is still running on half charge. This thing has an amazing battery life!<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. Hmmm...let's see. None!<br /><br />They designed this one really well and I'd be interested in knowing how they plan to improve upon this. Maybe send someone home to brush your teeth for you.

  374. This Sonicare brush has an auto shutoff function after two minutes (recommended brush-time length), and at each 30-second interval it will stop for a brief second to let you know to \\"switch quadrants\\". There is also a silver button you can push to select \\"Sensitive\\" mode, for your gums, and \\"Go Care\\" mode, for those that need to finish quick. The quality of debris removal is very good and my teeth feel squeaky after I brush. It's no replacement for flossing though, I still floss every night, but the Sonicare does a good job getting most of the debris out and off my teeth.<br /><br />I noticed that the brush head tends to get really dirty inside. I took the brush off and looked into the little pocket to find really nasty stuff in there. It kind of bothered me so sometimes I soak it in alcohol by take the brush attachment off, and wipe the metal rod. Also, don't leave your brush wet on the bottom. The rubber part tends to mold and it gets smelly. So make sure to wipe it dry before you leave it on the counter top.<br /><br />I charge my battery only when it tells me to so I can't comment on battery life when it comes to daily-charging. I've had my brush for over two years now. When I got this I was charging this about twice a month, and now I charge it twice, maybe three times, a month. The battery life is pretty good and the power is still just as good. As the battery weaken you will notice a decrease in power so make sure to promptly charge it when you need to.<br /><br />The set comes with two brush heads (a small and regular) but the brush head replacements are quite pricey! I'd suggest buying them in bulk for cheaper or try and use your brush longer than the recommended time. I generally use my common sense to determine if the brush head has hit its life's end. But don't wait too long because a bad bristle will decrease cleaning results. The charging dash is kind of awkward. It is a little wobbly sometimes it's hard to see where the prong goes into but it does it's job.<br /><br />I got my Sonicare brush for $50.00 at my dentist's office. Yes, I know, \\"What a deal!\\", but after using it, I think I would recommend it even for its normal price ($116.00 on Amazon), I certainly think it's worth the results and it will last you a long time. I can't say that it decreases cavities because I have generally healthy teeth but I do notice my teeth feel cleaner. If you are into oral health, this would be a great investment.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. Great clean.<br />2. Function options allow different styles of cleaning.<br />3. Battery/Power life.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. Price<br />2. Replacement brush heads are expensive.o but it does it's job.<br /><br />I got my Sonicare brush for $50.00 at my dentist's office. Yes, I know, \\"What a deal!\\", but after using it, I think I would recommend it even for its normal price ($116.00 on Amazon), I certainly think it's worth the results and it will last you a long time. I can't say that it decreases cavities because I have generally healthy teeth but I do notice my teeth feel cleaner. If you are into oral health, this would be a great investment.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. Great clean.<br />2. Function options allow different styles of cleaning.<br />3. Battery/Power life.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. Price<br />2. Replacement brush heads are expensive.

  380. This new electric toothbrush by Philips has a wide bristle range and special angled neck to provide better tooth coverage and a deeper clean. It makes it easy to reach hard to get to places in the mouth. In addition to a good cleaning job, it helps prevent gingival bleeding.   381. Packaging: The packaging of the device was appealing and organized. The pictures and the white coloring definitely inspired cleanliness. The listing of the features of the toothbrush on the box was short but still informative.<br /><br />Portability: The toothbrush comes with a travel case that is compact enough to fit in most toiletry bags, however, the brush head needs to be detached in order to fit in it. The charger is very compact and readily able to travel.<br /><br />Operation: The R910 features 3 brush modes: clean, sensitive, and massage. The clean mode was very intense and takes a little while to get used to, however, once you do it is definitely the most effective mode. It gets teeth very clean as the vibrations are at a significant amplitude. The sensitive mode is a good compromise if you have very sensitive gums. While it does not clean as thoroughly as the clean mode does, it is sufficient for daily use. I would personally not recommend using the massage mode. I felt that it did not make my gums any less sensitive than the sensitive mode, but the difference in cleanliness was noticeable. The R910 also featured timers and personalizeable routines which I didn't find useful.<br /><br />Overall: Overall, I would say that the toothbrush is very good. The brushes modes are definitely more effective than normal brushing. While the personalizeable routines weren't very useful, the brush modes more than made up for it.
  382. I have never used an electric toothbrush before this one - the \\"old-fashioned\\" way always seemed just fine. But since our dentist has recommended that we use a sonic toothbrush (he made no specific brand recommendations) I decided to give this a try.<br /><br />Another reviewer has compared this brush to a \\"bee\\" in your mouth. I'd say it's more like a jackhammer - at least to begin with. It took several days and some adjustments to my brushing style before I started to get used to it. I still find it annoying and almost painful when the shaft of the brush head accidentally touches my teeth but with practice I'm getting better at avoiding that. My previous habit was to brush for a very long time, but this model gives a slightly different buzz every 30 seconds to prompt you to change which part of your mouth you're brushing. I've gotten used to that as well, and am able to time myself a little better now so that I've covered all the teeth in each section. It still feels like it stops rather abruptly, however, when the 2 minutes are up but I guess I can always turn it back on, right? Unfortunately, us \\"low-tech\\" brushers don't get up to speed so quickly, and I'm still trying to figure out all the features this brush has, but it seems to work well on the standard setting.<br /><br />But lest you think I've hated this brush, I will agree that it leaves my teeth feeling exceptionally clean. I don't know if it works any better than the Braun Oral B that my wife and kids use, but I can feel a definite difference to a \\"manual\\" brush. My gums also feel better, and my thinking is that a sonic brush might be healthier for them. I like the feel of the rubberized grip, although the buttons are right where you hold it and I've accidentally pushed them before. And my only other complaint is that it comes with only a single head. For the high price of this model I would think it could have included a few. But overall, I'm sold on this one and will continue to use it... and try to figure out all those other features.re out all those other features.
  383. I love this toothbrush. One thing that really made the difference for me is the fact that there is significantly less vibration that other products I've used so far. Believe me, I love the tickle I get from holding the brush handles of my Ultreo Ultrasound, but after a while it gets irritating. What the makers of FlexCare have accomplished is to practically eliminate this buzzing in their product (by as much as 80% according to the statement on the box).<br /><br />Another interesting feature has to do with the bristles. I feel like I'm reaching some parts of my mouth a lot easier and I believe it has to do with the fact that FlexCare offers a wider sweeping motion and the bristles are more rounded than the average toothbrush. This combination makes for a more pleasant experience when after turning off the bathroom light and heading to bed, I feel refreshed. I guess the toothbrush does make a difference.<br /><br />I highly recommend it.
  384. After several months with no problems and a great dental checkup I have to say that this is one of my personal favorite tooth brushes.Most importantly is the cleaning.This brush does an awesome job,aside from a cleaning at the dentist I haven't found better.<br /><br />The size is smaller than other electric tooth brushes I have used which is a plus for me.It fits comfortably in hand and I haven't had any problems with accidently switching it off while in use as I have with other brands.<br /><br />The brush head is a nice size and feels comfortable in my mouth.It is not small but not huge either.Plus the replacment heads are easy to find and a reasonable price which is very important over the long run.<br /><br />I like being able to adjust the speed for when you need a more thorough cleaning and if you have sensitive teeth and gums you can always start at the lowest setting and work your way up to a faster speed at your pace,this would be very helpful if you are not accustomed to using electric tooth brushes.<br /><br />I have found that the battery holds a charge well and so far is still doing so.Plus the low battery warning is nice so it dosen't run out in mid-brush.Aside from just trying them out I don't really use the programmed settings.It's not that there is anything wrong with using them I just like brushing the way I always have.<br /><br />The FlexCare is a bit pricey but other than that I have no complaints.I liked this brush so much I bought one for my 8 year old daughter who has had dental problems since she first got teeth and she has had no problems using it,and loves it as well.
  385. I've owned a Philips Sonicare before this. I dont remember the model. But it was their top-of-the line brush about 4 yrs ago. It stopped working since the little green button got jammed. Both that model & this one have it sealed. So you cant fix it yourself, God forbid that happens. So go easy on that button.<br /><br />As far as the brushing action is concerned, if you have NEVER used a sonic brush before, then yeah - its great. I've read some reviewers stating toothpaste flying about. You have to be a \\"leetle stoopid\\" not to figure around this, if you dont get it right the first time. Just apply the paste about on all your teeth till there's nothing sitting on the brush head. Then operate it.<br /><br />Another comment was that the brush is a little loud. No its not. And I live in a quiet environment. Its not noiseless of course. Someone near you will hear it. Not the neighbours.<br /><br />It has a massage mode that is quite nice. You still brush with the same bristles really. But the pulses are more controlled.<br /><br />The 2 min brush cycle beeps every 30 secs or so to remind you to change position. Again, that's not a new feature over the old brush. Also, the most important point is IMO, the brushing action. I dont consider it to be superior to the prev Sonicare Elite. It did not feel that way at least.<br /><br />It does have one advantage over the older model. No housing recess for the magnets. So there's no stinky gunk buildup in that chamber. You'll appreciate this if you owned the earlier models. Otherwise, disregard.<br /><br />All in all, a good brush.<br /><br />No I did not waste money on the sanitizer. Use Hydrogen Peroxide 3% from your friendly, or otherwise neighbourhood chemist. The sonic action with the peroxide should shake the hell off any bacteria in the bristles. Dont waste money on the sanitizer please.

  396. Engineers look at functionality in a simplistic mechanical way.<br />Designers look for artful symmetry in design.<br />Both failed to collaborate to design a functional piece that takes into account human anatomy as well as basic physics. To place on/off/change buttons at the singular location, the fulcrum of our toothbrush lever, which is where the human hand needs to balance the forces of pushing against the teeth while still holding, shows a lack of creative collaborative thought.<br />Offsetting them slightly to either side would solve the problem of accidentally hitting those buttons. Having a programmable disable feature once brushing begins is another solution. Having buttons slightly recessed with a thin slide to cover is another.<br /><br />Interesting that manufacturer testing & research of how quickly the non-replaceable enamel is worn down by our now more abrasive head speeds that information is not being shared and makes me wonder what teeth will look like after years of use. Especially when combined with the more abrasive \\"whitening\\" toothpastes that have been out these past few years.

  416. My 8 year old Sonicare toothbrush died 2 weeks ago after a long and happy life, putting me back in the market for a new rechargeable toothbrush. I already knew I wanted a new Sonicare just because I had been so happy with my old one. I purchased a Philips Sonicare FlexCare from Amazon (the best deal I could find in any store!) and I couldn't be happier with it. Had I known how improved this newer model would be, I would have ditched my older Sonicare a long time ago to get this one! The brush head is a lot smaller, the toothbrush is lighter and the rechargeable base is a lot smaller too. Did I mention that clean feeling no other toothbrush can give you? If you don't have a rechargeable toothbrush, you have to get one of these. There's a reason they say Sonicare is the best. It is! You not only won't regret it, but you'll instantly develop an addiction to brushing your teeth. A bit pricey, YES, maybe, but considering the difference that it makes in your mouth, it's worth every penny. Happy brushing!

  422. Which is rare. Okay, normally, I wouldn't have given another philips product another shot given that I have had really bad experiences with their other products and they have all died very quickly with light use. Okay, I received this as a replacement due to a previous sonicare (which was a gift) malfunctioning. Okay, I thought it was a one off with the previous one so I thought okay, i'll give it a shot and it lasted way less time. This thing was dead in under 6 months. All I did that *could* have caused it something that would speak volumes to this thing. All I did that was \\"out of the ordinary\\" was wipe away some of the gunk accumulating between the brush and the handle with a napkin with some alcohol on it. Nothing too invasive. After this, it completely died. It took it about a week to go from weak vibrations to almost non-existant vibrations as in they were so faint that I could barely feel them there. It's inexcusable for a brush this expensive to die like this over just a simple cleaning (which I have done on everything from 20 dollar Oral B Vitality brushes to more expensive ones) with no issues but for this to die that quickly from the same level of treatment. This was my 2nd failure of a Sonicare (the 1st one just suddenly died after changing out heads as well). I will never buy another Sonicare product again, i'm going back to Oral B. That aside, if you are fine with frequent failures, I must admit their warranty service is good and the toothbrush does well at cleaning your teeth. Just don't invest in a lot of heads because you probably won't get the same model back in the warranty exchange (I didn't).
