  431. Using a manual toothbrush means when I am tired or in a hurry, I inadvertently skimp on brushing. Not with the Sonicare, it tells me when I can move from the front side to the back side and then from top to bottom or vice-a-versa, depending on where you start. There is also a in a hurry feature that gives you a quick brush for the aforementioned skimping situations.<br /><br />It was annoying when the head of the brush would touch the tooth when I was getting used to it, but now I no longer notice it when it happens.
  432. First, I don't own this model because I don't need the extra features. I own a cheaper Sonicare with replaceable AA batteries. I've read all over the places that people complaining the rechargeable products won't hold the charge after a short period of time. Products including wireless land line phones, cell phones, shavers, rechargeable Sonicare, rechargeable tools, ..., you name it.<br /><br />I bought a new wireless phone with 2 handsets several years ago. Both of the handsets could not hold the charge after one month of usage. Each handset has two AAA NiCd rechargeable batteries. I took the batteries out and found out that one of the batteries in each handset has died. Replaced them and both handsets have been working fine until now. Yes, I'm an electrical engineer.<br /><br />Here is my finding why the rechargeable batteries failed to hold the charge.<br />1. Product manufacturers use the cheaper battery (usually NiCd) which has inferior material and no QC at all.<br />2. NiCd has memory effect. Study by your own as what it is.<br /><br />How to use rechargeable products correctly:<br />1. If the product comes with lemon batteries(like my case above), then the following does not help.<br />2. Although Lithium and NiMn batteries are claimed to have no memory effect, I don't 100% believe it.<br />3. Regardless the type of batteries in the product, do NOT place it on the charger after each use. Put is aside not charging. Only charge it when the batteries are depleted. Suppose a new rechargeable can be charged 1000 times, you use one count each time you rest it on the charger. There is an explanation on chemical reaction with electricity but I don't intend to go over with it here.<br />4. Yes, the battery will loose power through its internal drain. Still, do NOT charge until power is completely out.<br /><br />Hope it helps. I'm not going to answer questions here because I want to live a simple life.
  433. I has having some tooth sensitivity and someone recommended this tooth brush to me. Since I started using it my teeth don't hurt anymore (I brushed too hard). Comes with one head, the brush, and the base. I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for an electric brush. The price might be a turn off but my mother has had the same base for 8 years now and it still works as it should!
  434. I tried the Sonicare and was really surprised by how powerful it is....even in the the \\"sensitive\\" setting. This just seems like too much. Saving time brushing will usually mean you are brushing too hard, and likely cause gum recession and tooth abrasion. You need to brush softly, but for between 2-3 minutes, 2-3 times/day (as well as flossing, which nothing can replace). \\"No pain, no gain,\\" does NOT apply to toothbrushing. I certainly would not recommend this for your teeth. I think if they can tone it down 75%, it might actually be good. The gum \\"massager,\\" mode makes no sense. Proper tooth and gingival care has more to do with the prevention of accumulation of plaque, etc., and \\"massaging,\\" the gum is just a great marketing idea. I think the only people who really need to use an electric toothbrush are those with dexterity issues, etc., and they may benefit from the use of an electric toothbrush, but the trade off, e.g. recession, etc., may not be worth it. Also, you can't really try to put less pressure on it, because then it will not clean that well. I can also tell you that you will spurt toothpaste all over unless you wait to turn it on when it is in your mouth...the vibration is just that harsh. If you accidently hit your tooth with it, and you will, you will feel like there is a jackhammer in your mouth! I know there are a lot of people out there who are huge fans of these....I am not one of them. If you are still considering this item.....You only get one head, so if you want to share this (if you are a fan) you will have to spend more on another head. It does come with different colored rings so you can identify different brushes, but those rings slip around, perhaps because of the harsh vibration (I pressed pretty hard to put the two pieces together). The actual quality is very good, and it feels sturdy and not cheaply made. I just cannot recommend something that makes my teeth hurt after using it, no matter how it feels, or how cool it looks (and it does look pretty cool and hi-tech). For about two-three percent of the cost of the Sonicare (and no operating cost) you can have a superior instrument to keep your teeth and gums healthy.s look pretty cool and hi-tech). For about two-three percent of the cost of the Sonicare (and no operating cost) you can have a superior instrument to keep your teeth and gums healthy.

  436. I'm on my third unit in about a year. Right at the top I must say the customer service from Phillips is fantastic, in each case a fast phone call and a new unit arrives in the mail along with a pre-paid shipping label to send the faulty one back.<br /><br />The first two failed when the brush head started to wobble and did not transmit vibrations to the business end. Inspection showed the metal shaft loose in the brush. Customer service indicated this had been a problem and they were supposed to re-engineer it. The second brush had the exact same problem.<br /><br />The third brush seems to gotten over the loose shaft and had been working fine for the past four months. This morning it was dead as a doornail. The battery was fully charged but nothing happened when I pushed the button.<br /><br />Once again a very pleasant person on the other end of the phone listened to my story and now I'm waiting for my fourth brush.<br /><br />Ironically prior to buying this I had bought a cheaper model, the Essence. Each time the Flex fails I revert back to the cheaper model and it works just great. I'm sure at some point I'll have gone too long for a free replacement and I'll just use the other one full time. I'd never buy a new Flex model again after my experiences.

I have moved residences when I was onto the second one so I know its not to do with voltage or something like that.<br />I know it's bad but I just by a new one from a retailer and pack the old one into that packaging and take it in for a full refund.   459. I have been using a Sonicare Elite for around 11 years. It was beginning to visibly wear and battery life was deteriorating so I decided to replace it with a new one.<br /><br />I like the size of the new handle. The buttons are placed such that the settings can be inadvertently changed. It would be nice if Philips could devise some way to unlock them for setting changes, maybe by holding a button for a few seconds. I doubt that I will ever change the settings from what they are currently. But this is not that big a deal. The brush head is a much simpler design than the Elite version and MUCH less likely to harbor residue that goes stinky over time like the Elite head. The new heads are also less expensive than the Elite heads, likely due to their simpler design.<br /><br />The charging base is very nicely designed and a big improvement over the one that came with the Elite. Cable management is improved too. I doubt I will separate the two pieces of the base for travel. If I am going to be gone long enough that I might need to recharge, the whole thing is small enough to take along.<br /><br />So far, so good!

  485. I first bought a Sonicare electric toothbrush in 1996 for about 90 dollars. It was a beast, but it always cleaned the tough parts of tartar and plaque off my back teeth with ease. Everyday felt like a visit to the dentist. It finally died in 2010-an amazing run for a rechargeable battery. I obviously wanted a replacement, and much to my surprise the line has expanded. The cost is reasonable, considering its close to the 1996 price.<br />The obvious differences are:<br />-Easier to clean heads<br />-Longer life between charging<br />-smaller form factor<br />-Smaller and easier to get into the back areas.<br />-Nifty battery display.<br /><br />The brush lasts so long on a charge it's been nearly a month since I got it and I'm still on 50%.<br />The brush has a higher frequency and is faster-a little offputting at first.<br />Overall, it's been great and the difference between this and a manual brush is an order of magnitude.

  488. I rarely write reviews, but this toothbrush is so bad I just need to warn everyone. I have been using an Oral B toothbrush for years, but tried to switch to Sonicare because I heard it was so much better. This thing is week. My teeth never felt fully cleaned. I am returning this and buying a new Oral B.
  489. I loved my original sonicare brush that lasted for so many years that I lost count. This flexcare broke in three months. The new pop on brush head is handy, but full of issues. The metal shaft that you pop the brush head on broke--now the brush just sort of flops around. I called customer service and found out that this is an known issue with this model. They are sending me a new one, but in reading reviews I found that other people are on their third or fourth replacement. I say stick with the older models.
  490. Vast improvement over the model I had 4 years ago. For I while in the last year I was using cheaper version of electric Sonicare toothbrush and there is no comparison. Thank you Philips!
  491. One of the best toothbrushes I have ever used. The multi function options are great. This is also a good gum stimulator. The replacement heads are expensive but last a long time.
  492. The unit's battery has failed and will simply not charge.<br /><br />I love the way this product performs, but I'm not sure what the anticipated life of this product is supposed to be. For $120 (plus the cost of replacement heads), it ought to last longer than 16 months.<br /><br />HOWEVER, this product has a 2 year warranty, so I called Philips CS. The rep asked me to try to reset the unit by placing it on the charger base and pressing the power button for 10 seconds. When that didn't do anything, she simply asked for the model and serial numbers (as well as my address) and said a replacement would be sent out (with a return mailing label to return the dead unit). I don't know if the replacement will be a new or refurbished unit, but so far dealing with Philips CS has been hassle free. Now we'll see how long the replacement unit lasts.
  493. Purchased in Oct '10 on eBay (brand new), but b/c it was a third party seller Philips said the warranty was void. I am fine with that, but it shouldn't have stopped working after 5 months.

  496. The Sonicare does a wonderful job of brushing. My complaint is the design. The button for changing Modes is in the wrong place and too sensitive. I am constantly inadvertently hitting the mode button while brushing. Very irritating. I would get a model without the mode button.
  497. I tried to save by buying the cheaper model, but that was such a bad idea. I returned it to Philips.<br /><br />I decided to buy this again because my wife missed it more than I did. Pricey, but great. Very powerful. Although, I like having the UV light cleaner charger instead of this plain charger.
  498. I've had the Sonicare for about 2 months now and I love it. My dentist said that she doesn't normally tell people to use a Sonicare unless they really need it, but that it's going to make your teeth feel like they've been polished every time you use it. It does make my teeth feel clean afterwards and it's so much easier to brush my teeth well. I had trouble knowing how long to brush my teeth, so the timer is probably one of the best features. The nice thing about the newer versions of the brush, like Flexcare, is that they have cheaper brush heads, especially if you buy them at Costco. 35 dollars for 7 heads. They recommend that you switch out heads every season, so 4 times a year, but you might be able to get away with longer. The battery life is great. I can take this on travel with me and it'll last at least a week, brushing twice a day. I never ended up using the extra modes, even though I thought they were nice to have. For people who are new to using the brush, it may feel awkward so they have the brush move slower at first and then get you up to normal speed, for the first 10 times or so. If you're already used to it, you can bypass the break-in speeds. Just read the manual for instructions. The carrying case will keep dirt off the brush, but you'll have to pull the brush head off to get it in there. It won't stop anything from hitting the button and activating the brush, either. So you may want to invest in a hard case if you want to travel with it. I didn't end up getting the UV cleanser because I didn't see any point in that--you'll just be replacing heads every so often. Since when did you ever UV clean your toothbrush? I never did, and I never plan to. Saves you a little bit of cash. The newer brush is lighter and better with energy usage compared to older versions, so that was part of the reason why I chose this one. Great brush, I definitely recommend to everyone if you can afford it.
  499. This toothbrush has exceeded my expectations. The grip and feel of the handle is excellent and the options provided are a pleasure to use, and I use everyone of them (clean, sensitive, and massage). Also, this brush performs far better than the previous Sonicare I owned; as a matter of fact, I am now brushing more than I ever have. I made my decision based on reading other reviews just as you are doing now. Then, I went to a drug store to hold one in my hand--that did it. I came home and ordered it. Amazon is the way to shop and I have made several purchases with them and have not been disappointed yet.

  511. I got the Philips Sonicare Flexcare upon the suggestion of my Dentist. It took about a week for me to get use to the vibration but once I did I thoroughly enjoyed the clean without the abrasion of using a \\"medium\\" toothbrush which was ruining my gums. I really like the fact it holds the charge for at least a week with 2 brushes a day so I can travel without the charger. I also love that it lets me know when to move on to clean the next quardrant of the 4 areas needing to be addressed. The only downside is I still use a medium toothbrush to brush my tongue but that's it. I am a true convert to the electric toothbrush.
  512. I bought this one to replace an older Sonic that I've had for the past six years. My old one served me well, but this newer model seems much more powerful. You can really feel the difference between brushing with a Sonicare toothbrush compared to a traditional non-electric toothbrush. Your teeth just feel much cleaner and the Sonic is especially great at removing food items that tend to get stuck in your teeth, such as popcorn. Yes, flossing works wonders, but if it's late at night and you don't feel like flossing till the morning, the Sonicare always comes through when a traditional brush just won't do.
  513. I'll admit, this is my first electric toothbrush that cost over 20$. I was going to buy an Oral B Pro 5000, but these were on sale for much cheaper. The flexcare is the comparable model to the Pro 5000, so I went with it for that, and also because I try my hardest to avoid P&G products because of their tendency to test on animals. Granted, I know they're not testing their toothbrushes on animals (though, that may help with lab animal dental care!) it just seemed like a worthy plus for Sonicare.<br /><br />It arrived, the packaging was surprisingly easy to break through, and I set about to charging it for 18 hours... just kidding, that's what the package says but I ended up charging mine for about 6 hours before using it for the first time. What? I just couldn't wait!<br /><br />I had purchased two of these (one with the sanitizer) because I was unaware how easy it was to change brush heads. It's literally just one placement. No screwing, you just place the head with the brushes facing the \\"panel\\". Now I realize I definitely could have just gotten one toothbrush for my spouse and me to share. Unfortunately, I just don't feel like a good person returning a toothbrush for no other reason than my own disbelief!<br /><br />My GOODNESS! This thing is powerful. The first time I used it, I actually wasn't sure I was going to be able to handle it. I only used it for about a minute, gingerly pressing it to my teeth before pulling it back, and this was on the sensitive setting. What power! It's now been a week, and now I can make the full three minutes of the \\"Max Care\\" setting and I look forward to an extra thirty seconds or so on the massage setting, which I just run over my gums where they meet my teeth.<br /><br />Here's what the settings are from what I can tell.. max care is three minutes of alternating toothbrushing gloriousness. It alternates regular speed with the massage. The massage is formulated for your gums, so I'm not sure if there's any benefit to this being in your toothbrushing routine. Go care is a minute of the standard speed, which apparently is for those of you who can't spare an extra minute to brush your teeth. If you neglect to choose go care or max care, you apparently get 2 minutes of \\"Clean\\" setting with little breaks in which it's suggesting you move to another quadrant of your mouth.<br /><br />I initially thought the little breaks were because I was pressing too hard and it was automatically stopping for that reason, but no.. perhaps I should have read my manual instead of just assuming. I wasn't pressing, really. ;)<br /><br />After reading my manual, I also learned that my first time wasn't even as powerful as it could have been! Apparently for the first 15 uses it doesn't vibrate at full power in an attempt to get you used to the toothbrush. If you read your manual, you can find how to turn that option off. I also learned it doesn't even have a setting to alert you if you're pressing too hard. I thought that was kind of standard for expensive toothbrushes.<br /><br />Anyhow- this item has made my teeth so happy. They're dentist clean on a daily basis, and I had to use a regular toothbrush as I forgot to pack mine for an outing and was appalled at how \\"unclean\\" my teeth were.<br /><br />So...<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Gets teeth wonderfully clean<br />-Lightweight<br />-Aesthetically pleasing<br />-Simple operation, made even more simple by reading the manual<br />-Nice options and settings<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Nothing to alert you of if you are pressing too hard<br />-Price point could be considered high<br />-Very STRONG and something to get used to at first<br />-Creates a lot of saliva, which your husband WILL fling at your just-washed bathroom mirror<br /><br />All in all, I think it is the MOST WONDERFUL ITEM I'VE PURCHASED. Well. This week at least. Again, keep in mind that I have no electric toothbrush to compare this to.outine. Go care is a minute of the standard speed, which apparently is for those of you who can't spare an extra minute to brush your teeth. If you neglect to choose go care or max care, you apparently get 2 minutes of \\"Clean\\" setting with little breaks in which it's suggesting you move to another quadrant of your mouth. I initially thought the little breaks were because I was pressing too hard and it was automatically stopping for that reason, but no.. perhaps I should have read my manual instead of just assuming. I wasn't pressing, really. ;) After reading my manual, I also learned that my first time wasn't even as powerful as it could have been! Apparently for the first 15 uses it doesn't vibrate at full power in an attempt to get you used to the toothbrush. If you read your manual, you can find how to turn that option off. I also learned it doesn't even have a setting to alert you if you're pressing too hard. I thought that was kind of standard for expensive toothbrushes. Anyhow- this item has made my teeth so happy. They're dentist clean on a daily basis, and I had to use a regular toothbrush as I forgot to pack mine for an outing and was appalled at how \\"unclean\\" my teeth were. So... Pros: -Gets teeth wonderfully clean -Lightweight -Aesthetically pleasing -Simple operation, made even more simple by reading the manual -Nice options and settings Cons: -Nothing to alert you of if you are pressing too hard -Price point could be considered high -Very STRONG and something to get used to at first -Creates a lot of saliva, which your husband WILL fling at your just-washed bathroom mirror All in all, I think it is the MOST WONDERFUL ITEM I'VE PURCHASED. A minor touch can activate it. This combined with the soft \\"Travel pouch\\", leads to frequent self turn-on when it is in your travel bag. Even though you know it will turn off in 2 minutes, you start digging for it when you hear it buzzing. I think Philips should come up with a retrofit solution to fix this problem.<br /><br />My other, smaller, complaint is about the grip. When it gets wet (or slimy)during its use, it becomes unnecessarily difficult to hold in your hand. The rubberized handle is smooth and combined with its small diameter it requires multiple readjustment in your hand while brushing.

  538. This model uses a lithium ion battery (the HealthyWhite also uses Li-ion). This is the reason I chose this product over oral B or the other cheaper sonicare models. All the Oral-B models that I could find used either NiCad (toxic) or nickel-metal-hydride (NiMH). Previous experience with NiMH batteries that they wear out quickly. And since you cannot replace the batteries in rechargeable toothbrushes, I didn't want to have to purchase another one in 2 years. I've had very good luck with Li-ion batteries in laptops, cameras, phones, etc. They hold their charge better and last longer.<br /><br />Justifying the price is difficult. Although I got a very good deal at a warehouse store for the flexcare with 2 handles and UV sanitizer. The replacement brushes are also more expensive. However, if I can get a few more years out of this because it uses a better battery, then the price will be more comparable to cheaper models.<br /><br />As far as cleaning ability, I feel that it is doing a better job than I would do with manual brushing. I would be surprised if the cleaning ability is significantly better than the oral-b models.

  549. My husband and I used this toothbrush everyday and it does a great job cleaning our teeth and gums. However, we have owned a new version of this toothbrush once a year for the last three years and that is my biggest complaint. We have to purchase a new one every year because the prong that attaches to the heads to the motor either loosens, the motor begins to lose vibration, or there is some weird glitchiness I might be inclined to blame on a malfunctioning battery. I would love it if this toothbrush was repairable, as in I could crack it open, reseat parts, change parts, or just be able to tinker it back to life. I don't enjoy spending 100 bucks on average for a toothbrush once a year. I really do expect it to last longer which is why we're no longer using the sonicare brand.   550. I bought this toothbrush one year ago to replace my Sonicare Elite. Overall I think the toothbrush does a great job. I mean, let's be honest - any electric toothbrush is going to clean your teeth well. The only differences are the design, the features and the brush head.<br /><br />1) Design - lighter than my elite, but one SERIOUS issue. The built-in stand on the bottom that it balances on isn't big enough! So, when you put your toothpaste on the brush and set it down for a second, if you nudge it it rolls right over and \\"pastes\\" your counter. This happens to us at least once a week and is so irritating<br /><br />2) Features - truthfully, I don't use any of them. The recommendation is for two minutes so that's what we do. I think the features are really a waste.<br /><br />3) Brush head - the toothbrush's design with the new heads is the best. For anybody with an older model using the old screw-on heads, I know you've spent a crazy amount of time cleaning nasty stuff out of the top of your toothbrush where the head screws on. The new heads are the best and completely eliminate the problem.<br /><br />Overall, I'm happy we purchased it. I wish we had one with a sensor that tells you when you're brushing too hard since this is an issue for me, and I REALLY wish the stand on the toothbrush was better so it didn't tip over. Very annoying and it seems like it would be so easy to fix!

  559. After 2 years the toothbrush keeps turning on by itself and there is no way to repair it or be replaced since my 2 year warranty is over. Up until that point, it was fine. Just a future heads up for those keeping it long term!
  560. My first rechargeable toothbrush was the Phillips Sonicare Essence that I kept for 4 years, and I was very impressed with it. When the battery started wearing down and the toothbrush had to stay on the charger till next use, I just decided to upgrade. After reading many reviews, I decided to purchase the FlexCare. I charged it upon arrival, and it lasted 10 days before the battery indicated it was low. Things I've noticed: The Flexcare is very nice, it is powerful, light weight, it has more vibrations and settings such as massage, max care and a few others. It also has a battery indicator instead of just dying when it's low. The design of the replacement heads are better than the Essence, excess toothpaste and stuff doesn't accumulate under the brush head, it slides on and slides off, and securely fits when attached. The handle has a type of vulcanized rubber on the back for a better grip, compared to the Essence that has a slick plastic finish. The FlexCare feels significantly lighter than the Essence, and leaves your teeth feeling clean and polished, like coming from the dentist. With that being noticed, I have also noticed that the settings such as clean, sensitive, Go Care and Max Care don't significantly differ, it seems they are just on a variable timer, the vibration doesn't seem to intensify, the settings just allow the cleaning segments to last longer than others. However, the massage feauture does allow the brush to have a different rythmic vibration that feels good on the gums. I like the product, I'm happy with it, and I would recommend it to someone looking to upgrade or someone just looking for a great toothbrush.
  561. I tried this toothbrush beginning in January 2012. I liked it very much. It cleaned more thororghly than the Braun I had been using. When it suddenly quit, I ordered a replacement from Amazon.
  562. This toothbrush works extremely well getting my teeth clean, Charge in unit lasts several weeks even with regular use, I recommend this product.
  563. Both my husband and I have been using this product for eight years. The initial brushes we bought had begun to lose their charge more rapidly and the mechanism was wobbling somewhat on one. We decided we liked them more than what has come out since and purchased two new brushes of the same kind. We find that we consistently get good results and our dentist concurs. Couldn't give any item we own a higher \\"we're pleased with it\\" rating!
  564. The toothbrush itself is good, but the customer service is TERRIBLE. My brush stopped working after a year and a half, and they just told me to buy a new one--as if I was stupid for not thinking about that in the first place. The supervisor I spoke with also told me that these toothbrushes are only meant to last for 3 years. When I buy a toothbrush that costs over $100, I expect it to last longer than that. I can buy a lot of other electric toothbrushes for that price that will last much longer than 3 years.<br /><br />Think carefully about whether you want to invest over $100 into a toothbrush, just to have to spend another $100 in 1.5-3 years.

  577. At the recommendation of my dental hygienist, I bought this Sonicare toothbrush a year and a half ago. I find it definitely more effective than a regular toothbrush. Also easier and maybe quicker to get the job done. The vibrating head was a little hard to get used to at first, but I adapted soon enough. This particular model has a lot of settings, but I only ever used two of them (Clean and Sensitive). So, for me, the other features were wasted. Next time, I'll get a simpler model. And the next time will be soon, because recently the indicator lights that show which setting the toothbrush is in went out one by one. The brush still works, but telling which mode it is in has become a problem. It's also begun to jump between settings on its own while in use. I guess a year and a half is a pretty good run, although for the price I expected it to last longer. In any case, the Sonicare vibrating toothbrush system is so effective that I will surely get a (simpler) replacement.

  594. I bought this toothbrush recently. I feel it is a value purchase. It take care of the dental care needs and takes your experience one step further to unique. Fast strokes and far reach. Prior to this Toothbrush I had a Oral B battery-operated brush which was not economical and wasn't as a strong a brush as the Flexcare.<br /><br />This toothbrush has 5 modes of cleaning. I normally use the clean mode which I believe is the fastest and most basic mode. That is what you will need most of the time. The handle grip is remarkably thinner than the Essence model and Oral B old models. I can say one of the thinnest and most comfortable handles in the market. The travel bag is another interesting feature which makes the experience great.<br /><br />I believe Flex care comes in two models. The basic model, that I own, does not have a UV cleaner for the brush but I heard that feature is not worth the extra 30-40 dollars you have to pay to get the non-basic model.<br /><br />All in all, I totally recommend the product.
  595. We bought one of these toothbrushes in 2008. (Not from Amazon). The first one went wrong and luckily we got it replaced under warranty. (We kept the receipt). Now that one has gone wrong...just won't work, even though all the lights are on and the heads have been cleaned or replaced. I understand there is an internal rechargeable battery that must ware out. If you go on YouTube, there are videos on how to fix it, but it doesn't seem that easy. Will probably end up plonking down the cash for a new toothbrush.<br /><br />Other than that, I love the feel of the toothbrush and it's hard to go back to a manual one after you've used the electronic one. I like the smaller heads as they make it easier to get around the back teeth. My husband has a lot of gum and pocket issues, so it seems to keep all that in check.<br /><br />Bottom line: Paying so much for a toothbrush, I would expect it to last a good 10 years, but I like the result you get from using it.   608. Updating my review here. I meant to do this a while ago.<br /><br />First off phillips replaced both of my handsets so I actual have a spare when one does die.<br /><br />second I made a remark to my dentist about how the sonicares kept breaking on me and he actual told me that the newer models have some give in the post to stop people from brushing too hard with them. If you press too hard you will over time damage this \\"feature\\". Apparently you can recede your gum line by pressing too hard with the sonicare and other electronic brushes. I think phillips could of done a better job explaining why this new design is in place and warn people. For those of you like me who didnt know about this now you do. I left my original review below.<br /><br />**********************************<br />I've been using the sonicare toothbrush line since 1998.<br /><br />My first unit lasted until 2002 when I purchased a elite model because my sonicare original broke (battery still worked but unit wouldn't vibrate).<br /><br />That elite model lasted me until may of 2010.<br /><br />I bought a flexcare elite with uv sterilizer in may of 2010 it died in April of 2011!<br /><br />I bought this flexcare in April of 2011 and it died the exact same way today as the last one did.<br /><br />The brush began to vibrate violently for probably 3 days and then this morning it \\"clicked\\" and lost all power. I can here it vibrate still but the head gets none of the power.   616. I'm on my third one. I keep buying the same one because the dentist said my teeth have greatly improved since I started using this brush. Before this brush, I used several other kinds of electric toothbrushes so it wasn't because I switched from manual to electric. (I did add GUM Flossers to my routine though.)<br /><br />I discarded the first one because the battery wouldn't charge after nearly a year. Philips replaced it for me at no charge because it was within a certain period of time from purchase. The second one also just died after approximately the same amount of time. Also the battery wouldn't charge but the manifestation was somewhat different. It's unfortunate that I have to keep replacing them but I will continue to do so if my oral health depends on it.<br /><br />If you are wondering why the battery doesn't charge, I really don't know. With the first one, I was very diligent about wiping it dry before putting it on the battery charger. With both I was very diligent about charging only after it they were on empty. I wish I could advise how to avoid your battery dying but I don't know. My husband has the same brush and his second one still works but his second charger died.<br /><br />Besides the battery life, I have only one other complaint. There is a gap between the brush head and the body of the brush. It's supposed to be there according to instructions but I constantly have to wash that area out and sometimes the brush head even falls off.<br /><br />Final tip: As with any electronic toothbrush, you should not apply it strongly to your teeth or use it for too long in one sitting. It's so easy to do because it's so easy to brush that you can lose yourself in a book and brush forever. I developed the equivalent of papercuts in my teeth in the places that I brush the most and hardest so try to avoid that.
  617. Philips offered a two-year warranty on my unit, which was just as well as the first unit died mysteriously after a year. They sent a replacement without issue, which started malfunctioning about a year after receipt--a raspy sound from within and the head stopped vibrating. While they worked they worked very well indeed, but be prepared to replace your unit.

Would not hesitate to recommend this to anyone asking for a good way of keeping healthy gums and plaque free teeth. After cleaning the teeth, you fell that they are so clean that you have a desire to constantly check that cleanliness with your tongue.<br /><br />What is also very important, is that I get less tartar to be cleaned by my dentist and my gums almost never bleed while I am cleaning my teeth (which was the case when I used a regular brush).

  634. They recommended this brand of electric toothbrush. Because I have sensitive gums, the sensitive and massage setting brush without hurting me. And, the bristles fade when it's time to change the brush. Great item!
  635. I've had this exact item for yrs.. Dentist recommended. I love it. My current one started acting &#34;funny&#34;, so I jumped quick, hopefully being able to replace it with same.   651. Philips has a good reputation or quality products. This toothbrush system incorporates some unique devices. The brushing routines are broken down into three modes; Clean, Sensitive and Massage. The latter will induce a tickling feeling. This device has a \\"quadpacer\\" which times the cleaning of your mouth into four quadrants, which is a nifty feature to make sure you brush long enough. This can also be deactivated.<br /><br />The charging stand is a little less sturdy than most but has two other places for brushed. Each brush can also be color coded for family use. Unlike a similar model by Ultreo, the brush heads are smaller. They are also much cheaper, coming in sets of three. The entire unit is approximately $30 less expensive than Ultreo. The overall look is slimmer. The carrying case is flimsy, unlike the hard plastic Ultreo case, but for the value, Philips Sonicare comes out ahead.<br /><br />The Quadpacer is a big selling point along with the smaller sized brush heads. You can be sure that you are brushing long enough and more thoroughly with this unit. The variety of brushing modes is also designed for the varied user.
  652. I didn't think that this toothbrush would be much different than the less expensive ones you can get over the counter now. Boy was I wrong.<br />This does an amazing clean job! My teeth, gums and tongue feel cleaner, longer through the day since I've started using it.<br />Besides the great job it does cleaning, there are a number of good points about it. First, it doesn't take up much space, which is a big plus. Second, it is very elegant looking, attractive. It charges in about 4 hours, which really isn't too long. A travel case comes with it, which is perfect to take with you instead of traditional toothbrushes.<br />The brush end appears to be delicate, but it is actually pretty strong. If you happen to press too hard while you're brushing, it stops. That is a big plus so you don't do damage to your teeth or enamel.<br />The vibrations this thing sends out as it's working feel like a wonderful massage to your mouth. I have to say, that's my second favorite thing about this. You don't get that feeling with the others.<br />But it's the cleaning job that has sold me. I've brushed my teeth at bedtime and woke up with a clean mouth! Amazing.<br />I strongly recommend this to everyone. It is more expensive, but well worth the investment.
  653. I'm essentially a lazy person. But after a year in which we spent five figures on dental bills -- gum disease is really awful -- we got religion when it comes to oral hygiene. Yes, I really *do* brush twice a day, floss, and all the things I'm admonished to do on my quarterly cleanings.<br /><br />We bought the older Sonicare units two or three years ago -- the \\"Elite\\" models. So when Amazon gave me the opportunity to try this new version through the Vine program, I felt that I could do more than say whether this *type* of product is worthwhile. I can give a real-world compare-and-contrast with the less expensive Sonicares.<br /><br />In short: yeah, it's worth it.<br /><br />The Amazon description gives you the basics of the way these gizmos work. The rechargeable brush vibrates in a way that does a deep cleaning, far more than you'd accomplish on your own. And the timer forces you to spend the right amount of time brushing. That's true of both the Elite model and this FlexCare model.<br /><br />The FlexCare has a few extra features, most of which I appreciate. Primary among them is that it has multiple settings, not just on and off. You can choose a two-minute mode or a one-minute mode; the brush gives you a loud hum and buzz-change to let you know when it's time to move to the next tooth quadrant (top outside, bottom outside, etc). The two minute setting includes a few seconds of massage for each quadrant, too, which is nice.<br /><br />The brush also has a setting for sensitive teeth (which would have mattered back when I still had the gum disease), and a massage-only setting (which is okay, but I haven't yet found a use for).<br /><br />The FlexCare is thinner, which makes it more comfortable for my small hands. The replaceable stem-and-brush is thinner, too, and they plug in rather than screw on. Mostly this is a boon for cleaning the brushes, as our older Sonicares could collect all sorts of goop; we had to unscrew 'em and rinse them out at least a few times per week. This model also charges faster than the Elite.<br /><br />My only complaint -- which is minor -- is that the button which you use to change the setting is a little hard to whack. It takes a distinct effort rather than a gentle touch.<br /><br />Overall, though, this is a great brush. If you care about your teeth, do get one!e Elite. My only complaint -- which is minor -- is that the button which you use to change the setting is a little hard to whack. It takes a distinct effort rather than a gentle touch. Overall, though, this is a great brush. If you care about your teeth, do get one!
  654. I had always wanted to try an electric toothbrush so was very pleased when this product came available via the Vine program. I have been using the battery-powered toothbrush for years but didn't realize how much more power the electric would have. I am totally impressed. I like the \\"Smartimer\\" letting me know exactly how much time to spend on brushing, I also like the fact that I don't have to spend as much time flossing. The Phillips Sonicare seems to take much of the excess plaque that I usually had to use floss for, thus really shortening the time I have to spend. The design of the handle is very comfortable, not as unwieldly as I thought it might be. I agree with those who have said that the handle does not fit quite as tightly on the charger as I would like making it very easy to tip off, but that is a minor complaint. The travel case is a nice addition. Only my next dental visit will tell for sure, but I definitely anticipate good news. I am totally impressed and recommend this product highly as do most dental professionals.

What a worthless brush that is. Yes, it's cheap but you don't get half as many rotations as you would with the older oral-b models. Can't forget after a year of use I was lucky if the charge would last a full week without having it sit in the charging cradle. You could also tell as the days went on that it was losing it's power.<br /><br />That Being said here are the pro's about this toothbrush: Smaller head then of the past sonicare toothbrushes. The charge definitely lasts more then a week without charge! I would say it would last just about a full 2 weeks without it sitting in the charging cradle. 2- compared to my oral b, i really love the \\"sonic\\" action you get with the toothbrush. I've had stuff stuck in my teeth plenty of times and instead of using floss(which is a better choice) i just use the one minute\\"go care\\" selection and bam, it blasts it away!. 3 you may not find this important, but the battery indicator is a luxury. I didn't have this with my past electric toothbrush, and without warning would have a dead toothbrush half way through my brushing!<br />4 All the different modes. When i say modes i really mean the \\"clean\\" , \\"go care\\" and max care\\" i believe these are the best and most used. The clean mode is for 2 minutes worth of cleaning, go care as i've mentioned above is for a brief 1 minute brushing for in between brushings, and the max care is my favorite- three minutes or 2 1/2 minutes of cleaning. 2 minutes of regular cleaning with about a minute extra of messaging. I can't forget the great feeling you get AFTER using this toothbrush. You get that just been cleaned by the dentist feeling- Nice and smooth every time!<br /><br />Cons: The extra modes that can be used with the 2 minute \\"clean\\" massage and sensitive setting really aren't needed since phillips added the\\"max care\\" that includes the massage with regular cleaning. The sensitive could come in handy but i never use it<br />2- the toothbrush automatically shuts off! if you aren't paying attention you might not have the best teeth cleaning that day. i dont really find this to be a huge problem. If i'm having one of those days and it just turns of, i just turn it on again and finish.<br /><br />3- this toothbrush is a bit pricey! To save some money do not buy it with the uv sanitizer. That's a major rip off and how much does that really work? When the bulb breaks you have to dispose of it properly due to mercury! so much for going green. Excluding the price, the few \\"extra\\" unnecessary modes, this is worth your money. I have never had such a good cleaning in my life excluding from the dentist.   661. First some background. We, my wife an I, have used Sonicare for many years. Our dentists have given both of us excellent reports on our dental hygiene. This is to say that the Sonicare toothbrush does an excellent job of cleaning teeth and gums.<br /><br />As mentioned, we've been using the Philips Sonicare for many years. Several months ago, we went on a vacation in Europe. Most European countries use a different electrical system than we use in the United States. More specifically, Europe uses 240-volts for their electrical outlets. In the Unites States, we use 120 volts. So, our existing Sonicare toothbrushes (designed for the Unites States) wouldn't work in Europe.<br /><br />We purchase these new Sonicare toothbrushes (those that are the subject of this review) specifically to use for our trip to Europe. We're pleased to say that these toothbrushes worked very well in Europe. Essentially, they worked the same as our U.S. toothbrushes worked in the U.S. When we returned to the U.S., we discovered that they work equally well on U.S. That is, they work very well on both U.S. voltage (120 volts) and European voltage (240 volts).<br /><br />So, the big advantage of these toothbrushes, besides their excellent tooth-cleaning ability, is that they will work in most countries of the world. If you're traveling, or even it you're not, these are excellent toothbrushes.

  669. The one positive: After owning several Sonicares over the last 20 years, starting with the very first model -- before Philips bought the original company -- I bought the new FlexCare mainly because the older models had a tendency to collect black mold under the brush head casing. My old Sonicare worked fine, but the mold issue was important to me.<br /><br />The new models have corrected this issue with a more waterproof seal between the brush head and the wand -- the brush head simply pops on and off on a pin that sticks up from the base.<br /><br />I chose the FlexCare chiefly because I missed a feature that was on my very first Sonicare -- a gentle speed in addition to the regular speed. The Flexcare choices seemed to offer that.<br /><br />The many negatives: However, the FlexCare has a frustrating design flaw in that the Mode choice button is directly below the On/Off button. And although the product instructions in the box say specifically that you must make your mode choice before turning the toothbrush on -- that you can't change modes while brushing -- the exact opposite is the case.<br /><br />The Mode button is just where it's natural to hold the toothbrush while brushing, and every single time I've used the FlexCare, it keeps changing modes in the middle of brushing because part of my thumb touches the Mode button even when I consciously try to keep my thumb on the On/Off button.<br /><br />Also, I see no difference between Clean (the choice at the top of the totem pole) and Sensitive (the next choice down). And Massage, which I thought would be another gentle choice for massaging the gums, is rough and hard -- like going over a bumpy road -- not soothing at all.<br /><br />When I'd asked my dentist which of the new Sonicare choices I should get, he said to get the simplest one -- and I highly regret that I didn't follow his advice. I am so frustrated with the FlexCare that I'm ready to throw it out after a few months' struggle with it and to buy a new Sonicare EasyCare at about half the cost of the FlexCare. (The EasyCare also has the new, slimmer pop-off brush head design that circumvents the old mold issue.)onicare EasyCare at about half the cost of the FlexCare. (The EasyCare also has the new, slimmer pop-off brush head design that circumvents the old mold issue.)
  670. I want to congratulate folks at Phillips/Sonicare on hiring the most talented engineers money can buy. With a precision of a swiss time piece they manage to estimate the life cycle of the battery to die right after the warranty expires. When I say “right after” I truly mean it. So you are stuck with a great piece of hardware that you have to throw it away because the batteries are non-replacable.<br />This is my 3rd (and last) toothbrush from them. In anger I had purchased Oral-B 7000 and could not be happier.<br />Sonicare vs Oral B<br />Sonicare handle feel more ergonomic than Oral-B<br />Sonicare vibrations feel more intense, Oral-B feels more mechanical<br />Sonicare non replaceable battery (deal breaker for me at this point) Oral-B removable battery<br />Oral-B separate display showing your brush time, warns you if you are pressing too hard. In addition, it has a nice LED light on the toothbrush itself showing you if you press too hard.<br />Sonicare- I always hated the crud one had to clean between the head and the unit. In addition if you are not religious enough about it, you will start getting mildew right under the rubber seal on the bottom of the handle. None of those issues are possible with Oral-B.<br />My overall feeling is Oral-B is more of a no nonsense get the job done type of toothbrush. While Sonicare is still riding on its ultra high rpm technology making you feel like your teeth are cleaner.<br />Bottom Line- both are great toothbrushes, but unless you are ok shelling our $150 every 2-3 years, Oral-B is a better buy.<br />Last but not least- Your experience may vary, but my teeth are cleaner with Oral-B. Not sure if a smaller head does a better job or it’s the technology itself, but I have definitely less plaque.

  698. Ive used a sonacare for years. I like this new flex-care, the massage mode is good for my gums and it switches to that mode at the end of each segment for a few seconds. The button on the handle is easily pressed which will switch mode so you'll need to learn how to hold it....and that takes some getting used to.
  699. I'm merely echoing other reviewers' remarks that this seems to be a well-designed and well-constructed product, but I'm astonished that a premium electric toothbrush like this would be shipped with only one brush head.<br /><br />Update, after several months' use: The brush has an annoying design defect--the brushing mode is too easily reset inadvertently, and you can't tell which mode is selected except by cycling through all of the five modes so as to light the indicator LED.<br /><br />Update 2: First off, Sonicare--to their credit--has eliminated the design defect I criticized directly above. My original toothbrush suffered brain death after just 7 months of use. Again, to their very great credit, Sonicare had a replacement brush on my doorstop almost before I reported the problem. It's this replacement brush (as of 1/15/13) that's been nicely redesigned: you can no longer inadvertently reset the brushing mode while you're brushing your teeth. It can, however, be conveniently reset when the brush is turned off. Clever design thereby eliminating an annoying quirk. And I'm still wowed by the courtesy and efficiency of the 1-800 people I talked with.
  700. This was a replacement purchase for a Flexcare that broke. The controls are somewhat different and not as intuitive as my previous model but OK after I got used to it. Package only contains a single brush even though there are spaces for 2 in the packaging.
  701. This worked great up till now.. no reason it just stopped. i thought perhaps it was the battery and called philips to find out that the warranty is 2yrs... however!! they have a grace period of 6 months and are sending me a new toothbrush base!!! Now that is good customer service.. i don't have it yet but should get it within 10 biz days.. if i don't update this, then that means we are a ok!

It takes up less space and seems to have greater vigor in cleaning my teeth. I am very pleased with this product.

  705. Bought this in October of 2009. It works great, definitely better than what my hand can do. Sadly it stopped working today. For some reason water got into the circuit board and damaged it. Now I have to order another one... or give Oral-B a try.<br /><br />UPDATE: Either this is bad luck or it might be the product itself, but my other 2 Sonicare failed to charge/stopped working 2 months later after this unit failed! I bought one on Amazon and got 2 from the Costco bundle. Overall 3 out of 3 sonicare toothbrush failed 2 1/2 years later. All experienced the same problem of being unable to charge. When the toothbrush is placed on the charger it just vibrate every few seconds. It no longer turns on and will not take a charge. Ticking time bomb???<br /><br />I eventually bought an Oral-B and felt that it cleaned my teeth better than the Sonicare did. I'll be sticking with Oral-B from now on. I really like the circular motion of the head better than the back and forth stroke from Sonicare. However one trade off is that the it is noisier and uglier than sonicare toothbrushes.

  716. I purchased mine in December of 2012. It lasted about a year and a half of very normal use. Well, my toothbrush began turning on all by itself and was difficult to turn off again. This continued for a week, where I would wake up at night, hearing it running in the bathroom. I had to get up, turn it off, only to wake up an hour later with it running again! I eventually had to sleep with my toothbrush, so when it turned itself on, I could quickly turn it off at bedside, without having to get back up and walk to the bathroom. Maybe it had something to do with all the ghost reality shows I had been watching on TV, but eventually it died (thankfully!). And at the expensive price paid, that Philips included ONLY one brush head is just plain greedy. Come on guys! And further, I never even knew what program I was using. My finger often touched the touch sensitive little silver button while brushing which then changed the mode, so I rarely knew what mode I was in and really did not care to take time to figure it out. I do think it did a great job of brushing, which was why I bought it, along with the knowledge that my last Philips electric toothbrush lasted a very long time. Not so this model, which has now ended my relationship with Philips, given the price paid. I deducted 1.5 stars for product longevity and for waking me up at night; 1 star for poor implementation of the programs, which are basically useless IMHO; and a half star for only including one brush head given the high price of this toothbrush. I would recommend Oral B and tests of equivalent models I've seen have shown Oral B to out clean the Philips. And hopefully, you will be able to sleep at night!

Trust me, although I do brush for the full two minutes twice a day, I am not doing anything out of the ordinary. I think for my third Sonicare, I may check out a different model.   740. My older Sonicare Flexcare toothbrush died after 2 years of use. My original one also had the UV light but I don't know if it was a gimmick or if it really worked but I really didn't use that feature. Once it died, I wanted to find a replacement, and this one was pretty pricey, but not as pricey as the one that that had the UV light. This works fine, and after using it, my teeth definitely feels cleaner. As the product says, there are couple of modes you can use. I just use the regular mode, where it turns off after 2 mins of use, which is I guess the time you should spend brushing your teeth. If you finish before it turns off, that means you aren't spending enough time brushing. The other mode is the gum massaging feature which I don't use.<br /><br />Replacing the head is easy but kind of tough, meaning you need to pull the head off, so if you're not that strong, or you have a broken wrist, it might be a challenge for you. This set also comes with a little pouch for when you travel but you need to take the brush head off first in order for it to fit. If this one breaks down, I would buy it again.

And I always have that fresh from the hygenist clean teeth feeling... but I still go to the dentist once a year for cleanings and checkups.
  787. I have had this model for about 2 years. I like it so well that I bought one just like it for my husband. It does keep a charge about 3 weeks as advertised. It can get dirty but is easier to clean up and to keep clean than an earlier model I had. It does a great job cleaning.
  788. As a mechanical engineer, \\"the little things\\" matter to me. The cheesy base this comes with slides all over the counte due to the chintzy rubber \\"anti-skid\\" pads that Sonicare chose to specify in order to save 2 cents per brush. I had some small, clear, 3M rubber pads on hand and solved the problem, after cleaning the base with rubbing alcohol.<br /><br />Why should I have to do this with a toothbrush in this price level? My original Sonicare's base remained in place for a decade. It also used a \\"plastic ring design that made reinserting the brush into the charging pad a cinch. Not so with this one, which uses a relatively tiny charging \\"male\\" that inserts into the female base of the brush.<br /><br />This brush offers five different brushing routines, but isn't \\"smart\\" enough to remember the last chosen setting. Hence, it must be reset each time you brush unless the default setting is your preferred setting. Additionally, the mode select switch (silver color) is poorly positioned and is prone to being inadvertently switched to another brushing mode during use.<br /><br />A well designed brush would include a \\"lock\\" for the mode select switch, which would \\"remember\\" and lock the last setting and require 5 - 10 seconds of continuous pressing prior to being unlocked.<br /><br />This brush is not a well thought out and thoroughly engineered product and I'm thinking about returning it. People should be fired for this.
  789. These are the best product for oral hygiene. Feels like you just left the dentist's office having your teeth cleaned every time you brush.
  790. A wonderful addition to dental hygiene, and a great price.
  791. I ordered this toothbrush to replace an older but similar Sonicare toothbrush. The order was shipped promptly and the product was exactly as described. Love the replacement more than than the original.
